TALK.START.PARA: —Before question time I was addressing the government's $1,061 million annual assistance program to local government and the failure of that program to allocate grants in a totally equitable fashion. The problem comes from two areas. Firstly, the allocation formulas do not use indices of socioeconomic advantage and disadvantage. They do not take a needs based approach concerning the provision of local government facilities and the capacity of various local government authorities. Use should be made of the 1991 ABS census index of relative socioeconomic disadvantage for each local government area in Australia. I congratulate the ABS on the production of that index because it is a great step forward for more equitable allocations of government resources.

PARA.TAB: The second problem arises from the requirement for 30 per cent of funds to be distributed on a per capita basis. The wealthy councils and local government areas with higher levels of private income receive funding. This results in $200 million, or nearly 19 per cent of federal funding for local government authorities in Australia, being allocated to the most advantaged 22 per cent of municipalities in the nation.

I would like to make some comments concerning the allocation of child-care funds. My reference is questions and answers provided in Hansard concerning the allocation of funding for programs in outside school hours care services, long day care, occasional care and family day care for the 1992-96 national child-care strategy.

The local government areas listed that receive funds offer no surprise when one goes to the answer concerning the funding formulas and the method of allocation. Socioeconomic indicators such as income levels are part of the background information in child-care regional needs analyses considered by the planning committee. However, socioeconomic status is not used in arriving at recommendations on areas to be targeted for new places. Places are allocated according to levels of unmet demand in each area. I am surprised by this. I would have thought that in child-care provision under the allocation of government funds socioeconomic considerations would have been paramount. The government should have consideration for those factors.

Not all local government areas are the same. In areas with lower levels of private income, there is a greater need for the public provision of child-care services. The use of the ABS index would prove invaluable in making sure that government funds for child care are allocated to where they are needed most. I would urge that upon the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence).

The debate has raised issues about equity and the allocation of government funds and also about states rights. I conclude by pointing out to the opposition that these parochial attitudes being developed by conservative state premiers around the nation are playing on the very worst features of Australian society and Australian values. They are appealing to uncertainty and fear about distance and isolation—things that this nation should be overcoming by using technology, transport and telecommunications, to bring Australians together rather than to pull them apart under this phoney banner of states rights—and playing up to these fears around the nation. That has occurred with not only the Tasmanian criminal code but also the native title legislation, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pointed out in question time earlier today.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address a few remarks to the pride that I know the city of Mackay in Queensland feels about the success of Cathy Freeman in the 400 metres yesterday, establishing a Commonwealth record time. I must say to Cathy that what she has achieved on this occasion has been very well received and has earned the respect and pride of all the Mackay people. We applaud her for her efforts.

PARA.TAB: It is not only a tribute that Cathy pays to Australia and to the city of Mackay, where she was born and reared and had her early athletics training—and I know the course she trained on—but also a significant aspect of being an Australian that you have to have respect for yourself and respect for your culture. Achieving a win like this reflects so much on that.

My only regret about the win is the means by which the media has plagued this lass for carrying a symbol of her race demonstrating her pride and respect. Watching the replay on television and the manner in which she then received the Australian flag and carried it makes me believe that, had the Australian flag been available to her in the first instance, she would have carried it as proudly as she did her own flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, we agree, but your side didn't.

—I do not want any interruptions, because I think it is important that we look very carefully at the manner in which the event—simple but historic in itself—has been used by the press. I am not being mischievous to members of the press, but to harass the lass after a huge triumph in the manner in which they did and to put her under stress on the basis of her not carrying the Australian flag does not give credit to those people.

PARA.TAB: I have seen other games where black salutes have been offered in response to winning events, showing a support of black power. I do not believe that that was any part of Cathy Freeman's intention. She only wanted to show that, as an Aboriginal, she has pride and respect in herself and she has achieved not only for Australia and Mackay but also for her race and culture.

I have had complaints rendered to my office today voicing a different opinion about the carrying of the Aboriginal flag. I want to put on the record that my pride in the lass is shared by everyone in Mackay. I only hope that she goes on with that in sight for the Olympic Games that are yet to come. Bear in mind that, being only a 20-year-old, she has already participated in two Commonwealth Games. That gives her a lot of credit.
There have not been many people of Aboriginal descent in athletics. But the history of Australia shows that Aboriginals have served many other sports, many of them very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rugby league.
—Rugby union. I believe that the Aboriginals have made a bigger mark on rugby union than they have on rugby league.
—The Ella brothers.

—The Ella brothers are who I am thinking of. We are talking about race. I did not have a chance to speak about the South Sea Islanders. One traditional South Sea Islander—Mr Mal Meninga, the Australian rugby league captain—has come to form. He is an example which proves that those who suffer so much deprivation within our society—both the Aboriginals and the South Sea Islanders—are able to achieve in certain circumstances.

PARA.TAB: While I criticise the lateness of the government's response to The call for recognition, which was rendered to the government about 20 months ago, I applaud the manner in which it has been received by the government. Positive aspects of the report were highlighted in the House today and, more particularly, at the wonderful occasion we had on the second floor of this building, where we recognised certain features that have been carried out by the government in so many ways. Such features include inter-island visits, the retention of the heritage, the building up of some of these places as traditional areas and the grant of $80,000.

I am afraid that I am a bit sceptical about this grant, because running another committee for another research program delays the justice that these people should really receive. I hope that the government proceeds as quickly as it can in that respect so that justice can be granted to the South Sea Islanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the words of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) regarding Ms Cathy Freeman. That young lady can stand tall not only as an Aboriginal achiever but as an Australian. Having recently been in Mackay and knowing what a close-knit community it is, I know that it endorses his feelings and the feelings of thousands of other Australians about her mighty achievements. She can also stand tall as a woman who has achieved.

PARA.TAB: I particularly rise here this evening to speak of a proposal for a medium density fibreboard plant at Georgetown in my electorate. This proposal is incredibly exciting for the people of Georgetown. They have copped some pretty hard knocks in recent times. Last year, Georgetown lost its ferry service to Port Welshpool, and there is continuing speculation as to whether Comalco will remove its operations from the area. This proposal will mean a $90 million investment in the Georgetown area. Seventy jobs will be created in the construction phase of the project, and 126 new permanent jobs will come on stream when the plant becomes operational. One of the most important points about this plant is that it will create annual export earnings of over $70 million. This contribution would be incredibly positive for our nation's balance of payments deficit.

This is a strategic process for Tasmania. It will be the first plant of its kind in the state. The potential for expansion is enormous. At the moment, worldwide demand far exceeds worldwide supply for the product. This is projected to continue well into the next century. There is the distinct possibility that there could be further plants created in Tasmania to produce this project.

The initial idea for this type of development came from Kevin French Enterprises. Whilst Kevin French is not involved in this development, he still sees the possibility of a second plant in the same area under his control in the future. This proposal is an all-round win. It is a win for the people of Georgetown through the development of jobs and development; it is a win for the people of Tasmania as it represents the beginning of increased investment in the state; it is a win for the country nationally through additional export earnings; but, most importantly, however, it is a win without environmental costs. Let me explain how.

At the moment in Tasmania, we are in the happy position of having a surplus between the current maximum demand for hardwood pulpwood and the annual sustainable supply. The requirement of this plant will be 250,000 tonnes of resource per annum. At least 200,000 tonnes of resource will be hardwood species, with the remainder being plantation softwood sawmill residues. This level of resource comes well within the level of surplus that Tasmania now has. I must stress that none of the resources for this plant will come from environmentally sensitive areas or even those areas that are in dispute as to their environmental value or sensitivity.

The plant will utilise cutting edge technology so that it operates well within acceptable environmental levels. It will be well situated over one kilometre from the closest population centre, and noise will be kept to a bare minimum with the use of state-of-the-art noise reduction equipment in the chipping process. The wood dust created by the plant will be at very low levels, even at the plant's own boundary.

This is a simple process which is very clean. It will help an area of Tasmania which is in need and value add for the country. But it will have to be approved by the Foreign Investment Review Board. I am sure that I do not have to inform members of the House that every minister has an ability to have an input into the Foreign Investment Review Board process. I have risen tonight to make this House aware of the virtues of the scheme and to ask all those who do have an input into this approval process to consider a number of facts.

Georgetown is in an area of northern Tasmania which needs confidence, stimulation and investment. The people of Georgetown are a resilient lot, but they need business investment in that area. The process is sustainable and clean. I am glad to say that it has the tacit approval of the Tasmanian Greens for this very reason. This is genuine downstream processing and value adding at its best, creating significant export earnings for the nation.
Assuming there are no unforeseen delays, this plant will start taking wood by the middle of 1996. That will be a great time for northern Tasmania. I commend this project to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-four years ago—in 1970—in Edinburgh, a Jamaican girl, Ms Marilyn Neufville, set a world record of 51.02 seconds in winning the gold medal for the 400 metres event at the Commonwealth Games. It has stood as the games record until now. Little did anyone realise at the time that it would be another three years before the person who would beat that games record was even born. That person, of course, was Ms Cathy Freeman, who won the women's Commonwealth Games 400 metres event in Victoria, Canada, yesterday with her record breaking 50.38 seconds. The defending champion, the Nigerian, Ms Fatima Yusuf, was second, while the Jamaican, Ms Sandie Richards, came third.

PARA.TAB: The run was particularly special because, in winning, Cathy became the first Aboriginal woman to win an individual event in any sport at a Commonwealth Games. As a 17-year-old, Cathy shared the 4 x 100 relay gold at the Auckland games. I can remember as a teenager the first Aboriginal males to win gold—Percy Hobson in high jump and Jeff Dynevor, the Queensland bantamweight boxer in the 1962 Perth games. Cathy recently set the Australian record of 50.18 seconds in a run in Europe and will surely become the first Australian woman to go under 50 seconds. Remarkably, she has been a 100 metre and 200 metre sprint specialist. She has been serious about the 400 metre run only over the last year.

Born in Mackay, Queensland, Cathy grew up there, although she is now based in Melbourne. Most of her family live in Brisbane. Her father, Norman, separated from her mother, Cecilia, when Cathy was five. Cathy found that a difficult period in her life but, even though Norman died last year, I am pleased to say that he reconciled his relationship with Cathy some years ago. Cathy has two younger brothers—Garth, 18 and Norman, 20. The latter was the Australian under-17 100 metre and 200 metre sprint champion in 1990. She also has an older brother, Gavin, who is 33. Sadly, her sister, Anne-Marie, died from cerebral palsy in 1990 and Cathy had to attend her funeral on the day of the coming home parade after the Auckland games. Naturally, Cathy's mother, Cecilia, and stepfather, Bruce Barber, are both thrilled at Cathy's latest success. As Bruce said, we have only started to see the best of Cathy.

Regrettably, considerable media hype has blown up since the brief comments by a member in this chamber about Cathy carrying the Aboriginal flag after her fantastic win. As I am a keen athletics fan, I was watching the race live on television, so I saw what happened after the race in context. Cathy was obviously delighted with her win. As soon as she caught her breath, she raced to the fence to get an Aboriginal flag of hers from a supporter in the crowd who was holding it for her. Cathy had packed this flag and carried it with her in her suitcase so she could display it if she won the 400 metres—`just in case I won', to use her words. She wanted to display it to the world; to proclaim her pride in being an Aboriginal. While I understand that some people would have misgivings about this action, it should be emphasised that, within a few steps, Cathy also sought out from the crowd an Australian flag to carry. We then saw a very happy girl walking around the stadium soaking up those special moments that only gold medal winners can experience. It was a fabulous event to behold and I am sure that all Australians were celebrating this fabulous victory.

While I understand fully the argument that we do not want all ethnic groupings from Australia displaying their special flags after every win, I do think that this occasion was different and special. I do not pretend to be able to explain it logically, but here was our first female Aboriginal gold medal winner on display. It was very emotional for all of us, and I would think more so for Aborigines and Cathy herself. Here at last was a wonderful success for the Aboriginal race, in the great tradition of Evonne Goolagong-Cawley, Lionel Rose, the Ella brothers and the like. We all call for Aboriginal success stories and Cathy gave us one. But it was not only a success for Cathy or for Aborigines, but also a success for all Australians. Cathy was mature enough to realise that and carry both flags. It was a joyous event for a gracious young girl and her audience, but also something far more powerful.

I believe that Cathy's actions were not out of place for the occasion. I do not believe that anyone should deny Cathy her moment of special glory which we all shared and I am confident that she is mature enough to handle any such occasion in future with equal aplomb. She has been a great role model for Aboriginal children in a very genuine way, trying to inspire these people to rise and better themselves in this world, and I believe that her attitude in this should be applauded. No doubt she will also perform well in the 200 metres, although I do have some misgivings there because Melinda Gainsford used to live up the road from me in Narromine in my electorate, and no doubt it will be a great contest between the two. I also look forward to Cathy's performance with Melinda and the other Australian girls in the relay. If the rest of Australia could cooperate and work together as these girls will, Australia would be a better place to live in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the comments made by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and I suggest that he look at the great achievement of Aboriginals over the last 200 years—surviving. Tonight I would like to discuss comments about ANL. The Australian National Line has been under a cloud of controversy over the last few days. Figures brought forward, particularly from 1988, have shown that the results of ANL have been less than favourable. I suggest that shipping is very much a barometer of world economic activity, and world economic activity since 1988 has been as rocky as the results that ANL has produced.

PARA.TAB: The health of land based industries is reflected in, for example, the building trade. When the building trade is in decline or is at the bottom and not doing well, it is usually a reflection of the same sorts of activities going on in manufacturing industry and other land based industries. It is on that basis that I suggest we look at the full 10 years of ANL's results. When the world economy was healthy, ANL was doing a good job. We should look at it on the basis of where we are in the world geographically. We are an island and we cannot get away from that. The Australian National Line has given us more than just profits in terms of what it delivers in expertise from the operation of the company—it delivers us positions on international boards controlling shipping. It gives us a say in what happens in terms of shipping. Ships of shame has been a world recognised document which has shown that this parliament and this country have taken a leading role to stop loss of life and try to improve the situation for both the operation and the quality of services provided in the world carriage of goods over oceans.

I suggest that we look at the trucking industry in Australia. If honourable members go back a few years, they would remember the days of the shonky operators and the trucks having dodgy registration checks. That industry was substantially cleaned up for the betterment of the whole of the Australian population. I believe that ANL is a vehicle which this government can use to clean up what is happening in world shipping. World shipping is in a state of disaster. To get the world fleet up to a standard of safety for ships 12 years old would require $400 billion. There is not the capacity in shipyards around the world to do that. As I understand it, the average age of ships is 18 years.

Clearly, we need worldwide focus on and action addressing this problem. Although my beliefs are contrary to popular belief—Mr Speaker, you know that I do not always swim with the tide; I sometimes swim against it—I feel that this government should be putting massive injections of capital into ANL. I do so with a number of reasons in mind. Firstly, we are an island; secondly, if we are going to export to the rest of the world we are going to have to do it by shipping and; thirdly, if we lose control or influence in the shipping industry in terms of shipping rates, we are going to be at the mercy of the rest of the world.

Whilst it may seem a short-term goal to take away this seeming problem or to privatise ANL, I suggest that, in the long-term interests of this country, we have to recognise that we are an island, that there are seas between us and that, if we want to continue to import and export, we have to have—whether we like it or not—a significant role in shipping. To have that role in shipping is a responsibility of this government. I believe that if we cannot run a shipping company we should not be running a government. I believe that we should be putting money into ANL and capitalising ANL to an extent to which it can compete.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak this evening about a moment that we all dread, a moment when perhaps we attend a doctor's surgery and are diagnosed with cancer. Of course, we know that cancer today is not a death sentence. Indeed, a great deal of cancer is operable and can be treated, and people do respond to that treatment.

PARA.TAB: I bring to the attention of the House a report that appeared in the Newcastle Herald on Friday, 12 August about one of my constituents who is in hospital suffering from cancer of the prostate gland. He had been advised that his treatment could not continue because the radiotherapy device that was necessary was not available. The queues were too long. He was left in hospital without the support of treatment. By the middle of the following week, the cancer had progressed so far that he had effectively become a paraplegic.

Last week, another of my constituents, a former seaman, came to see me. He was obviously distraught. He bared his chest—it was a pretty big chest—and showed me a couple of tattoo spots on his chest. He held up a copy of the newspaper and said, `Listen, mate, when things go this far, it's gone too bloody far. I am concerned. I have been diagnosed as having lung cancer. I have had one treatment and I have been told that I can get the next one in six to eight weeks.' He is concerned because he does not know how far that cancer will spread through his body by the time he can get the next treatment.

Last year, we heard the stories of women in the western suburbs of Sydney having mastectomies because they were diagnosed as having breast cancer and they knew that, if they waited for radiotherapy that would most likely cure their disease, it could advance so far that they were placing their life at risk. That is the state of radiotherapy in Australia.

It was very interesting to hear the minister speak yesterday about whose responsibility it is to provide the resources for this treatment. Obviously, it is the responsibility of the states. As a representative from New South Wales, I have done some research into the provision of radiotherapy and into the provision of funding for hospitals in New South Wales. I find it a disgrace that, in 1992-93, the Fahey government in New South Wales underspent its health budget by some $82 million—enough to provide in the order of 82 linear accelerators that are necessary to provide radiotherapy for the people I am talking about. Of course, the Hunter region essentially requires only one. We are focused on one of the fastest growing areas of Australia. Currently there are two linear accelerators that can be used for radiotherapy. I have spoken at length with Dr Chris Hamilton, who is the director of radiation oncology at the Mater Hospital. He advises me that currently the demand is for about 2.3 to 2.7 linear accelerators. That is based on the resident population in the Hunter. But we serve a much wider area which means that the demand is really for about three or a little more.

I am not sure how many people will die while we wait for the Fahey government to accept its responsibilities, but obviously people are dying and people are distressed. The government in New South Wales is currently crowing about the amount of money that it has to spend in this year's budget.

I urge all members to look forward to the amount of money that will be spent on health, on the sort of treatment that is vitally necessary for those people who are very concerned about the future of their own life. They are suffering from something that is treatable but which cannot be treated because of a government decision in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) on the research he did on what I believe is a very topical subject at the moment—the life and times of Cathy Freeman. The honourable member deserves credit.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I want to address is one with which you, Mr Speaker, would be familiar—the Martin banking committee, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which you chaired, and some of the recommendations that were made. They were not recommendations to government but recommendations to the banking industry and to consumers.

As you will recall, Mr Speaker, being chairman of that committee, the committee sought to have mediation entered into with a view to relieving the burden of legal costs borne by both parties—more particularly by the consumers themselves, because they were obviously in a state. At the time of our investigations, there were disputes with the banks concerning foreign currency borrowings. I am pleased to say that mediation is taking place, although it may not be taking place as expeditiously as we thought it would. It is taking place in a minimum number of cases.

The matter of concern to the committee at the time of the inquiry was the cost of legal expenses and how they could be reduced. This is very much a weapon in the hands of the banks—as it is in the hands of any big enterprise in Australia—if somebody wants to take such an enterprise to court on a civil matter. So there are a few problems.

There tends to be a reluctance—I am not talking specifically about banks now; I am talking about big business—to get legal representation to mount a case against big business. It is almost like the golden rule: he who has the gold makes the rules. In this case the big companies with an unlimited amount of resources can afford to take a case to the extreme—to appeal, reappeal and everything else that a plaintiff cannot do. They have access to good legal representation and to continued representation.

When a plaintiff makes a claim against a bank or a big company he knows that his resources are going to shrink—and there is no guarantee of success in this game, particularly with the appeal mechanism. The plaintiff has dwindling resources. Even if the plaintiff wins a case—and this has happened so many times with foreign borrowers—on appeal he may not be able to get proper representation. It is quite often the case that a QC who acts initially for a plaintiff and gets a favourable result is not available to take on the case on a continuing basis and to take it to appeal. This has been a major disadvantage.

I will give honourable members an example of an extreme case involving foreign borrowing. It has been through the court system, the appeal system, and it is still going on. On this occasion the bank was trying to bankrupt the individual involved—this would not have been difficult because the individual did not have a cent to bless himself with—and it proceeded to bankruptcy proceedings. One would have thought that simple bankruptcy proceedings would have required the plaintiff—on this occasion the bank—with one legal representative. However, on this occasion the bank was so determined to get a conviction that it brought along a QC and six other lawyers, as against one representative for the person concerned.

I raise this question not only because of the ability of big companies to buy their own justice—I use that word deliberately—but also because they know that in the ultimate those legal expenses, which in some individual cases have amounted to over $1 million, are tax deductible. There is a case to be made for the Australian Taxation Office or the Treasurer (Mr Willis) looking very carefully at this aspect of the cost of legal expenses and their deductibility for the big companies that pursue litigation to the extreme in the knowledge that they will win in the long term

SPEECH.PARA: because they will knock the other person out of the ring.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter of major concern. It has continued to be a worry since the inquiry which you headed, Mr Speaker. I hope that the Treasurer will look at this issue and perhaps give the committee a further reference so it can look at the tax deductibility of the outrageous legal expenses that are incurred.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 June.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I prefer that you move the motion while standing. The procedure is the same as in the chamber. You are obliged to be on your feet.

—My apologies, I thought I could do it sitting down. To continue, the purpose of the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is to repeal obsolete legislation and to make minor amendments to other legislation. The bill repeals the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1930 and the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1933. These acts, which were amendment acts to the principal act, the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, are entirely spent. The principal act will remain in force.

PARA.TAB: The bill also repeals the National Fitness Act 1941. This act was enacted because of concerns about the physical fitness of Australian youth for military service during the Second World War. The act established a national fitness council to advise the minister and a trust account, the National Fitness Fund, for moneys appropriated for the purpose of furthering the objects of the act, including setting up state fitness councils. The act fell into disuse during the 1970s when the functions of the Commonwealth and state fitness councils were taken over by other bodies. The National Fitness Council was phased out in 1975 and the National Fitness Fund was last used in 1986. The bill provides for the balance in the National Fitness Fund, currently $129, to be transferred to consolidated revenue.

The bill also amends the Christmas Island Act 1958 and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955 to enable the parliamentary secretary responsible for territories or another minister to exercise the powers of the minister under these acts. Currently, powers under Western Australian laws in force in the Indian Ocean territories are vested exclusively in the responsible minister, who delegates the powers to the parliamentary secretary. This amendment will simplify administration matters when there is a change of minister or parliamentary secretary.

The bill makes three amendments to the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. Firstly, it makes it clear that the definition of `Commonwealth agency' does not include any person in the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory or Norfolk Island governments and their instrumentalities. Secondly, the bill provides that it is not compulsory to make regulations to extend the criteria in the definition of `ecological community', as there is currently no need to extend the criteria. Thirdly, the bill removes a contradiction in the act with reference to the review function.

The bill also amends two references in the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park by replacing the old name with the new. The name was changed by proclamation from Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park on 27 May 1993. The bill also corrects an incorrect reference to a section number.

The bill repeals obsolete parts of the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974. The National Estate grants program operated under the authority of this act. Following amendments to the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, the program has operated under the latter act since the 1991-92 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I will be able to go through the procedure a little more correctly than the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon). I am delighted that you gave him some latitude in the carrying out of his duties.

PARA.TAB: This bill, as the parliamentary secretary has said in the second reading speech which we now have before us, is really an administrative procedure to deal with some acts which need some changing and some amendment. The opposition has no particular disagreement with any of those changes. Certainly, we have no disagreement with the change of name for Uluru, and we have no disagreement with any of the other changes that have been promoted.

However, as several of the bills amended—for example, the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975—are across my shadow portfolio I would like to take the opportunity, and I think it is appropriate, to make some general remarks in regard to those two areas.

In regard to the endangered species problem, because of which the 1992 act was passed, I really think it is time that this country had a look at whether it is succeeding or failing to deal with the problem of what is becoming an increasingly large group of the wildlife of this country. Is the Commonwealth, for its part, improving the situation or holding the situation? Does it understand the dimensions of the problem? Has it really understood the interrelationship between the feral pest problem and the deterioration in the number of native species in this country over the last 200 years?

It is difficult to separate the problem of endangered species from the feral pest problem. The feral pest program began in 1992-93 and it has been allocated about $2 million a year. It has environmental objectives, including saving endangered species and conservation. It does not receive much money, especially as almost daily we hear that we have large groups of species that are on the endangered list. As I understand it, most of those funds are for research and eradication. That is something that we do not object to as long as the research comes up with solutions to the problems.

The endangered species program, which receives $5.4 million per year, is really, as I understand it, combined with the feral pest program where that includes a feral animal problem. That $2 million for the feral pest program includes any joint state-federal projects. Does the government believe that those programs are succeeding?

It is not all the fault of the federal government, because states have many responsibilities and plenty of power in the area of the species that exist within their borders. The states have the power to promote the rejuvenation of species. They have the power to lock them up. The Commonwealth needs to provide some sort of leadership in a combined attempt to make sure that as much as possible is done to change the deteriorating state of our native species.

Let me just come back to the point about feral animals. In the last few years—I think mainly because of the efforts of a lot of private individuals who have been very concerned about these things for a long time—the fox and the cat have probably been identified as the major destroyers of the smaller Australian native species. Everybody knows that pound for pound the feline is probably the best destroyer in the world. Whether you are dealing with small cats in this country—which are getting larger, I might say, the more feral they get—or whether you are dealing with larger ones in other parts of the world, they are a very successful predator, the most successful perhaps, although some people believe that the fox has done as well in destroying our native animals.

Having been involved in agriculture for a long time, I think that what has been missing in this whole matter is that the goals of eradication of these feral populations have never been laid down by anybody. I have never seen, at state or federal level, a goal to eradicate any of the major feral animal populations. Yet I would have to say that in the case of the feral goat it would seem impossible that we could not put down a plan, a set of goals, to eradicate that very dangerous species.

It is a dangerous species for two reasons: firstly, because it is a destroyer of Australian native habitat, as it has been in northern Africa and southern Europe in a way that probably will never be recovered, but, secondly, from the disease point of view, particularly foot and mouth disease. With no borders in this country it runs rampant and is obviously very dangerous to Australia's domesticated stock.

So I have never understood why we should not be able to set goals in place whereby we set out to deal with those problems. That is not to mention the rabbit population, the brumby population, the donkey population or the fact that we have the greatest population of feral animals of any country on earth. Perhaps the federal government does not understand that. Perhaps the federal government thinks that it is appropriate enough to wander around the world signing treaties, some of which—or most of which, perhaps—we will not be able to abide by while we have this deteriorating situation in our own country.

I would suggest to the government that in the process of doing this research on endangered species we broaden our mind-set and do not adhere to the view that governments are the organisations that can preserve and conserve things. That time has long passed. Many other countries in the world now understand quite clearly that it is probably individuals who, for one reason or another—whether they simply have a great heartfelt desire to do so or whether for reasons of earning a living or for more grandiose reasons than that—make the greatest contribution to the saving of some of these animals.

One need only draw attention to the much quoted and much known elephant program in Zimbabwe which, by means of some processes which some people abhor, has managed to give some equity in that elephant population to the local people, who have turned out to be the great protectors of those animals in the face of an almost rabid ivory trade trying to poach them.

I suggest that we have not succeeded in this country. In fact we have failed mightily, and there are many people at fault, not the least of whom are the people who sit in this chamber. Therefore, we should open our minds—and, perhaps, our purses. If we are to set goals about eradication of feral animals and the expansion of our native species, then we have to do it with science and with resources, and we have to use all of the available information from around the world.

I will finish on that subject by putting on record in this chamber the dimensions of the problem that we are dealing with. I know it is impossible for people to be absolutely sure about numbers, but cats are known to hunt and kill over 100 species. Only the other day at Roxby Downs, I saw the contents of the stomach of a cat which had been shot by the Western Mining people's environmental group. There were 32 different and undigested reptiles in the stomach contents of that cat. In other words, they had been consumed in the previous 30 hours, I am told.

Cats can consume 100 species of native birds, 50 mammals and 50 reptiles, and numerous frogs and insects. You might in passing ask what has happened to the frog population of this country in the last 10 or 15 years. I will bet that there is nobody in this chamber who understands that our frogs are disappearing. They are simply disappearing from Australia at an unbelievable rate, and nobody knows why; although there are various causes which are possibilities. Again, we do not know the population of cats, but the possibility is that there are somewhere between four million and 18 million feral cats in this country. I have no idea, but let us call it 10 million. That is an enormous population of predators who, pound for pound, are the best destroyers in the universe.

Rabbits are on the increase, again. Perhaps not so much in the high rainfall country where myxomatosis is still operating but across that great band of country from southern Queensland through western New South Wales and across the north of South Australia and the south of the Northern Territory and into the Western Australian pastoral country they are simply out of control. I do not say that it is easy to set goals to deal with the rabbit population. This country is the best harbour for rabbits that they have ever found.

Quite frankly, rabbits are a terrifying problem and are probably doing more damage today than are almost any other animals—including the domesticated ones, where they are overstocked. We have to really put some resources into this, and very urgently. The rabbit problem is being addressed around this country, bit by bit, but the effort is disparate: it is not a coordinated, combined effort. We can extend the debate on that subject on another day. But the estimate is that the rabbit problem has caused about $100 million worth of damage, and I would think it is much more today, as rabbit numbers expand.

The feral pig is here in numbers which, again, are probably out of control. Again I say, why could we not, with a proper program, eliminate the feral pig from Australia progressively from the south? It is not an impossibility. Maybe Queensland and the top end of the Territory will be tough but, until we narrow it down and get a lot of effort concentrated in one area, we will never do it. So it is geographical and strategic planning that needs to be done.

The brumby, the camel, the horse and, as I have mentioned, the goat are a problem. While the parliamentary secretary is here, I will mention that I was at Shoalwater Bay the other day, and I was absolutely horrified to see that, on the federal government's own land, those islands are just jam-full of feral goats. Even I, at my advanced age—with a couple of young fellows, a motorbike, a set of yards and a barge—could get rid of them all, if someone would like to give me the contract. It is just nonsense that those animals are still there. I understand that they were put there years ago so that itinerant sailors who happened to get wrecked would have something to eat. That must have been 150 or 200 years ago; so they should go. The areas that are controlled by the Commonwealth should be dealt with first.

This brings me really to the second point that I wish to make. This bill covers the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and amendments to it. Australia's management of national parks has been less than perfect, and in some cases downright pathetic. With respect to the feral animal problem, nobody knows what feral animals are in what parks and in many cases they are not being properly dealt with. In some areas feral animals are spilling out of national parks onto pastoral land. I know that to be a fact. In many cases, people are feeding the feral animals from the parks on improved pasture and on pastoral land. I do not think that that was the purpose of setting up national parks. I think one of the purposes was to preserve, in its proper sense, what was there before with as little interference from the human species as possible. In some cases it is to preserve them for multiple use, for people to enjoy.

Leaving that aside, there is also an enormous weed problem in these national parks. When I go around Australia it does not hit me that we are conducting a massive program, supposedly coordinated by the Commonwealth and perhaps resourced by the Commonwealth, to deal with these problems. As the parliamentary secretary knows, even that rather good, rare, dry land species, the athel pine, is out of control in some parts of northern Australia. We need to deal with the problem—whether it is horehound, or African boxthorn, or whatever it is in whatever park. We also need to deal with the massive problems on the Queensland coast and the Northern Territory coast.

Bit by bit we are losing parts of Australia, whether it is from farming—which is my pursuit—or from weeds, feral animals, salinity or whatever. This issue should be regarded as part of the national infrastructure. It is as much part of the infrastructure of this country, perhaps more, than a road to Darwin and back. If that infrastructure does not stay there, and as time goes on, this country will simply deteriorate.

Let us get back to national parks. I raise the example of the Mungo National Park. The Mungo National Park is a park in south-western New South Wales. It is north-north-west of Balranald and north-east of Mildura. It comprises some 370,000 hectares of land. Owing to the presence of a very ancient dry lake, which dates back to the ice age, the park has significant records of Aboriginal heritage and past climates preserved in the landscape. However, after 13 years of being an area that has World Heritage listing, there is still no management plan.

A couple of years ago, the Commonwealth and New South Wales put in place a plan to plan a management plan. This is a ridiculous lack of strategy. All of the people who live in the area are still in the position where they do not know exactly what is going to happen to them. I notice that, as part of the 1993 agreement, a study will take place to assess the impact of World Heritage listing—13 years later—on the pastoralists who live in the area. This is what has been happening.

I do not want to be too unfair, but this government has been in place for the last 11 years, though there have been previous governments at fault. But as time has gone on, governments and the people of this country have come to realise the extent of some of these problems. We knew much more in the 1980s than we knew in the 1970s and we know much more in the 1990s than we knew in the 1980s. But 13 years after the announcement of the World Heritage listing, we are still doing a study to find out the impact on the locals, and we do not have a management plan.

Will the study include the drop in value, if there has been one? Will it include any increase in value? Will it include any cost of compensation? I will bet it will not, but it should. After all, the government imposed a new set of conditions in one form or another, with some obligations and some ties back to UNESCO, on some people who live there, without a plan. I have no problem with the listing of World Heritage areas as long as it is done properly and the listing requirements are properly complied with.

It might just be the time to finish on this note by saying that today the listing requirements require the full approval of the local community. The nomination has to be in accordance with section 41 of the World Heritage listing requirements, which I think were changed in February 1994. Those listing rules are altered quite regularly. They say that the nomination should be prepared in collaboration with and with the full approval of the local communities.

That is terrific, seeing that the current Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is trying to list the Lake Eyre basin, at least 38 per cent or 40 per cent of the Lake Eyre basin. Not the Parliamentary Secretary's part of the Lake Eyre Basin; he obviously talked him out of that. Not the Queensland part of the Lake Eyre Basin; the Queensland Labor Party has talked him out of that and told him to go and jump in the lake—not Lake Eyre but any other lake. Not the New South Wales part, which is eight per cent or whatever it is, but only the South Australian part.

The minister is obviously trying to do it without the full approval of the local communities. The rules say that there should be a management plan. He could not possibly have a management plan for Lake Eyre because he has not got the approval of the locals, which he needs if he is going to have a proper plan.

I will not go on with it. But all of those things need to be addressed. It brings me back to the Willandra problem. Of course, the Mungo National Park is in the Willandra Lakes area, and there is a national park which, again, has not been properly managed.

Perhaps with those few remarks we might be able in this place to start to address the problems, which are mighty. Last week I flew around Western Australia in a light aircraft at the right height to see the still encroaching salinity problems of that state. Unlike some of the salinity problems of the east, they may be able to be dealt with. But to see that happening in front of your eyes at an ever increasing rate brings us now to the point where we really need to address these problems with all of the resources that are available to us, both in the Commonwealth and around the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow minister for environment and heritage, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), indicated, this is a bill with a wide range of provisions. Listening to the shadow minister, I was interested to understand how in politics you can become expert on feral animals and weeds, although in my seat of Werriwa I think some of my constituents would be more interested in weeds than feral animals.

PARA.TAB: My intention is to address my remarks to the provisions of the bill concerning amendments to the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974, which in turn allows the Commonwealth to agree with the states on various forms of federal assistance for approved programs such as urban expansion, sewerage and water supply. I will be concentrating not so much on the environmental part of the bill but on those parts affecting urban and regional development.

In the south-west of Sydney the main employment opportunity comes out of an international airport at Badgerys Creek, potentially the largest job generating project in Australia. A study by the National Institute in December 1991 showed that the combined impact of the airport would create more than 30,000 jobs over 20 years through construction, airport management and, most significantly, the clustering of manufacturing and tourism industries around the airport site. That is where it is linked to this legislation. In developing the land around the airport site, which is a great economic development opportunity, the provisions of the 1974 Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act could be used by the Commonwealth government to assist with the economic expansion and the reticulated services.

The issue of the development of the airport and the urban and regional development consequences raises the question of the suitability of these major economic projects within Australia's federal system of government. In trying to get these major public and private development projects moving in Australia, we pay a price for a federal system of government. I am concerned, in relation to Badgerys Creek airport, that the involvement of three federal instrumentalities—the Department of Transport, the FAC and the Environment Protection Authority—the two state departments of transport and planning, a range of public bodies needed to service the land and two local government authorities will not produce an environment which maximises private investment on and surrounding the airport site.

For instance, I attended a briefing session with the FAC a few weeks ago where it was explained that aeronautical and industrial activities, in the absence of freehold arrangements, are unlikely to be attracted onto the airport site. Freeholdings can restrict the future planning and expansion of airport facilities. Moreover, the FAC sees no further role for itself in the planning and airport development of Badgerys Creek other than on commission from the Department of Transport. Already potential investors in aeronautical activities, such as PJP Aerospace and Defence Industries, have been disheartened by the confusion.

It would be desirable, therefore, to release industrial and commercial land surrounding the airport site to allow the development of a range of private sector investments. It has always been envisaged that the greatest employment growth from Sydney west airport would arise from these activities. Moreover, the absence of industrial zoning and activity will limit the airport's potential for freight movements.

Unhappily, I can report to the Main Committee that the New South Wales government is not yet keen to use its planning powers to fast-track these rezonings and to take up the opportunity from that 1974 legislation. Anne Cohen, in her marginal seat of Badgerys Creek, remains an obstacle to progress. She is more worried about the value of her own land in the vicinity of the airport site than about the potential for 30,000 new jobs in her electorate and those electorates surrounding Badgerys Creek. Further, the cooperation of Penrith and Liverpool councils would be required to achieve the desirable outcome. With the stalled development of the MFP in Adelaide, Sydney west airport and the associated development of transport links and economic activity can be Australia's largest development project.

It warrants consideration of a development model free from local, state and federal rivalries and competing objectives. This is where the 1974 legislation, amended in this bill, can be used and developed. With the agreement of the New South Wales government, a development authority could be established to handle all aspects: first, the airport's design, construction and transfer to private sector investment; second, construction of the rail link, exploiting any potential for private investment; and third, the release and development of industrial, commercial and residential land surrounding the airport site.

The employment benefits of this project can be maximised only by a coordinated and dynamic approach. The federal government, using that 1974 act and in cooperation with the state government, can develop complementary legislation. A model is already there for the Olympics at Homebush Bay, where the development opportunities do not need to jump through the hoops of local, state and federal government but rather there is one authority getting on with the job and the employment opportunities. In the early stages of the airport debate at Badgerys Creek, the prospect of integrated development—airport construction, transport links and land development—was the most attractive proposition for large investors such as B plus B development. This type of development can best be achieved under one planning authority. It is the brightest hope for private ownership of Sydney west airport after 1999.

This issue of private ownership and Badgerys Creek brings me to the question of FAC privatisation. The government has said that the airport and the regional and urban development opportunities will only proceed at Badgerys Creek if the FAC is privatised and the government realises the financial benefits. I am indebted to my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) for an assessment of FAC privatisation. He circulated a paper and asked seven questions that needed to be answered about FAC privatisation. I mention these to the committee in the context of this very important urban and regional development opportunity for my electorate and south-west Sydney.

The first question from the honourable member for Melbourne is: has the FAC's performance as the owner and operator of most of Australia's major airports been satisfactory? On this question we need to go, as ever, to an independent source. We have a report by the Prices Surveillance Authority which is very critical of the pricing policies and investment criteria developed by the FAC. Further, we have a statement made in the Australian Financial Review on 27 July by Singapore Airlines about its concerns and suspicions regarding the FAC, accusing it of inefficiency and a lack of accountability. The airline has a whole range of concerns: that the FAC will not improve its standard of information flow; provide a clear assessment on rent; and get moving with the best activities for Singapore Airlines. There is condemnation of the FAC from two independent sources: the PSA and one of the major airlines in this country. I would have thought that, in answering the first question, the evidence shows major concerns about the operation of the FAC.

The second question is: who owns and operates airports in equivalent countries overseas? We know that in Australia there are 400 airports in private ownership—or, at least, non-FAC ownership—including Cairns. At Cairns airport the charges are three times the level set by the FAC at Townsville, yet Cairns has five times the passenger movements per annum and a better link to regional and urban development. That is an important consideration out of this bill before the committee. There are several precedents overseas for private ownership and its value—in Asia, the United States, Britain and other parts of Europe. There is no concern about the question of what happens overseas, because those countries have demonstrated that private ownership of airports leads to a better incentive for urban and regional development surrounding the airport site. In Australia, at Cairns airport, which is owned by the port authority, we have seen a better link between the operations of the airport and the activities and promotion of the regional economy.

The third question is: how appropriate are the cross-subsidies which currently permeate the FAC network? The FAC uses the same pricing structure at each of its 23 airports, irrespective of local demand and cost factors. Investment and trading strategies hinge on flawed cross-subsidisation practices. A lack of transparency for subsidies between airports and between aeronautical and non-aeronautical activities makes the financial performance of each airport difficult to measure. The grouping of cost and revenue information for seven airports—Hobart, Cambridge, Alice Springs, Tennant Creek, Bankstown, Camden and Hoxton Park—makes an external evaluation of their performance impossible.

By breaking up the FAC and its monopoly practices, the government can achieve a more rational allocation of airport resources in Australia. Full cost pricing can turn around the financial position of smaller airports and can enhance their attractiveness for privatisation, or at least establish a proper basis for community service obligations. This again exposes the opportunity for urban and regional development, because privately owned airports will want to link with activities in the regional economy and to involve themselves in the sort of promotion and development that could trigger the 1974 legislation.

It is also very important to understand that, stripped of debt, only two airports out of the FAC network are not profitable—Mount Isa and Jandakot. There should be no confusion about the profitability of airports once they are stripped of debt. There are only two out of the 23 which would not perform independently, free of debt, once they were privatised. Small airports will not close. I am sure the government would look after community service obligations for Mount Isa and Jandakot and that those airports would remain in operation. As a consequence, the government can move on, knowing that other airports are able to achieve operation and profitability in their own right. These things are important for urban and regional development and we should all be interested in them.

There is also the argument about full-cost pricing. There should be little concern about privatised airports charging high prices for airport usage. Use of Cairns airport has not been set back by high prices—in fact, the opposite has occurred. Cairns airport has five times the passenger movements of Townsville airport, which is operated by the FAC.

If there is an increase in prices, who will pay? A person does not need to be Einstein, or even Barry Jones, to work out that the rich pay because the rich are great users of airports. Working-class, lower income Australians are not high users of Australian airports. It is wealthier people who pass through the passenger gates. The increase in prices is not likely to be substantial because airport related charges make up only three per cent of the cost of domestic airline tickets and five per cent of international tickets. Moreover, airlines spread ticket costs across all their routes and airports, both domestic and international. In terms of equity, there is a very strong argument to say that the people who use airports can afford to pay and, in any case, the increase in prices will not be substantial because of the low impact of airport related charges to ticket prices, domestic and international.

The practice of cross-subsidies for Australia's airports can hold back regional development. This brings me back to the point about Badgerys Creek and the 1974 legislation. By making a substantial profit at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport there was no incentive for the FAC to develop Badgerys Creek airport as quickly as it should have and as demand in the regional economy warranted.

The fourth question from our colleague the honourable member for Melbourne was: what impact would privatisation have upon the future delivery of airport services to the Australian community? In many respects, the question about privatisation for the FAC was lost when it was corporatised. It was at that point that the government said that this is an economic and transport activity that can operate according to the rules of the private market. That is why it was corporatised. From that point forward people have logically asked, `If it is operating under private market rules, why can't it operate under private market ownership?' The role of government and the usefulness of the FAC should have generated more controversy and more noise at the stage of corporatisation than it has at privatisation.

The great benefit that comes out of privatisation is the financial motivation to perform. Government corporatised bodies do not tend to experience the rigour of survival in the market that comes out of private ownership. There is a better financial motivation to perform. So there should not be any scaremongering regarding the extent of increased charges—they are spread across the industry and have a marginal impact on airport consumers. Privatisation of the FAC will bring a whole range of benefits to the government budget, financing the white paper initiatives and other aspects of urban and regional development.

Perhaps the government could consider a policy statement on privatisation to say that it stands as an infrastructure dividend, that the money raised goes back into the development of infrastructure that is not supported by the private sector. Under the current plan, of the $2 billion to be raised from FAC privatisation only $90 million is coming directly back into infrastructure. That is at Badgerys Creek airport, the very important urban and regional development project for south-west Sydney.

The fifth question was: is there scope for significant competition between airports? It is important to recognise that there are varying degrees of competition. There will not be competition at Perth airport because of geographic isolation, but for airports in closer proximity—Hobart and Launceston, east and west Sydney, Coolangatta and Brisbane—there is an opportunity for some form of competition. It may be limited, but it can be significant in consumer and business benefits.

The other benefit is that the cost system arising from a competitive framework leads to a better operation of airports. When airports have their own cost centre they stand or fall on their own financial performance in terms of capital development and extension of the airport facilities. Cross-subsidisation practices will no longer be artificially propping up some of the regional airports and leading to bad investment decisions, such as the excessive amount of finance that was poured into the development of Darwin and Townsville airports. These are investments which have not realised benefits to the government or to the public relative to how that money could have been better invested in other parts of the public sector. Isolated cost centres will solve that problem and mean a much more rational and efficient allocation of economic resources from the public sector.

The sixth question was: is selling the FAC airports likely to produce an optimal financial outcome for the federal government, or are there better alternatives? The argument here seems to rest on the views set by Professor Bob Walker from the University of New South Wales, who has stated from his research that the net sale proceeds are likely to amount to between 57 and 78 per cent of the real value of the assets to the federal government.

In truth, the value of an asset is only realised when it is sold, and the revenue capacity of that asset is built into the sale price. This is a flawed model promoted by Professor Walker that relies on a theoretical construction of companies and company options. I know it is flawed because when I worked in the New South Wales parliament he was known as `rent a result Walker'. He was not beyond gearing up these results to suit the commission he had received from the interested authority. I have no time for his sort of research. It is absurd to say that the federal government would only realise between 57 and 78 per cent of the real value of the assets. Honourable members know that assets only have a real value once they are sold, and revenue streams are built into the sale price as investors try to take advantage of future revenue opportunities.

Equally, I have no time or consideration for Bill Swingler, the Managing Director of the FAC, and his assessment that the FAC is worth more as a whole than if broken up for sale. Four of the airports are the main profit makers. They will realise more finance for the government sold separately than by tying them down in a single sale where they have to continue to prop up, by way of cross-subsidisation, the weaker financial performance of other airports.

The seventh question was: what are the implications of privatisation for airport and airline workers? I am pleased to report to the committee that the Transport Workers Union supports the proposition, so the main body of workers is covered in this proposition. Perhaps some of the other unions are more comfortable with the cosy relationship they have established with the FAC, and they have a fear of uncertainty in industrial relations and the environment that follows thereafter. But they are not concerns that loom large in the public interest as defined by the government and parliament.

I have answered the seven questions as best I can. They relate specifically to Badgerys Creek airport, which is a major regional economic development opportunity for my electorate of Werriwa in Sydney's south-west. That in turn relates to the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974 which goes to prove—I know my colleagues agree—that it is a very broad bill which allows members to bring in all matters—from feral animals, to weeds, to endangered species, to urban and regional development, to the FAC and privatisation questions. As those opposite have kindly pointed out, the debate will continue in other places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are quite amazed on this side of the House that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) should give his initial draft speech for the Hobart conference here in this chamber. We have some difficulty in relating contents of this bill to endangered species. We wonder whether Barry Jones or Senator Evans are endangered species. We look forward to the honourable member's advice on those matters.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting to hear the point of view and range of arguments that the honourable member for Werriwa put forward, compared with his colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), who I know has a fairly strong view on the privatisation or otherwise of airports around Australia. We look forward to the re-run of that speech in Hobart and to seeing how he gets on with the numbers. I understand the numbers as to whether his side or the other side will win are very finely balanced at the moment.

I wish to support the remarks made by my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the shadow minister for the environment, about endangered species and the policy surrounding those matters. The shadow minister has had a lifetime of experience in these matters in pastoral Australia. He has been very close to the problems that rabbits, dingoes and donkeys have caused to a number of our endangered species throughout Australia.

I point out to the chamber that problems do occur in other parts of the world. We in Australia can ensure that some of our endangered species survive by putting some incentives in place to encourage the private sector to support the survival of these particular animals and plants. As the shadow minister quite rightly pointed out, there are a number of feral animals causing terrible destruction to our native animals and fauna. The cat population in Australia is estimated to be between four million and 18 million. In Victoria both the former Labor government and the current Liberal government looked at cat registration. They were concerned about the number of cats moving from the urban areas to the country areas and causing terrible destruction.

The number of brumbies or wild horses is estimated to be 600,000, if that is possible. Their destruction of plants and water points, and the general pressure on the stocking rate, is of great concern to pastoralists throughout Australia. The camel and donkey population, which emerged as a mode of transport from those early imports in the 1850s, seems to be about 150,000. Again, especially with the donkeys, it is a considerable problem that is difficult to control. It is hard to round them up and it is hard to get rid of them.
Our goat population is estimated to be two to three million. Any honourable members who have anything to do with goats will understand the capacity of goats to eat grass.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have them in the Liberal Party every day.

—No, the goats will be down at the Hobart conference. The real goats have a great capacity to eat a lot of grass and to eat plants—native or otherwise—to a very low level. The damage they do can be quite devastating over a broad area, wherever they might graze. As the shadow minister mentioned, the rabbit population is in the vicinity of 100 million. Every Australian understands the background to the importation of the rabbit for sporting purposes and how that rabbit population got totally out of control.

PARA.TAB: The wild pig population is about 70 million. The pigs are very active in the Daintree forest and I have seen the destruction they have caused. The authorities have gone to great efforts to keep people out of the Daintree but the pigs are creating much more of a problem with their nightly destruction of the vegetation. People have had a very small impact on that area.

With respect to the feral cat plague, I want to refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on October 26, 1992. The headline reads `Feral cat plague devastating fauna'. The article goes on to say:
Feral cats are sweeping through remote environmentally sensitive regions of the outback in such numbers that some of our endangered species may be wiped out by the end of the year.
"The number of them out there is just obscene," said Dr Jack Pettigrew of the University of Queensland.

Dr Pettigrew has been working for the past three years in the Diamantina region—recognised as the most important habitat in Australia for the endangered bilby, and also home to one of our rarest birds of prey, the letter-winged kite.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Pettigrew went on to say:

PARA.TAB: There could be as many as 18 million feral cats in Australia, each one needing about 300 grams of flesh a day to survive—the equivalent of about 10 small mammals.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister reported his own experience last week in South Australia of the devastation caused by one particular cat eating some of these mammals. In broad terms, we can see that these feral animals are having a devastating effect on both the vegetation and the native animals of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I would like to draw the attention of the chamber to the example of the elephants in Africa and the way the world community is trying to maintain the elephants. As honourable members would be aware, the price of ivory is a very key factor. The world community has therefore banned the trade of ivory but then of course a black market developed where prices could be built up and the encouragement to poachers became even greater.

Under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, the African elephant was placed on the list of endangered species. It was hoped that by putting it on this list and banning the trade of ivory the African elephant numbers would be improved. I just make the observation that the ban on alcohol in prohibition America exemplified the fact that prohibition itself did not reduce the consumption of alcohol.

The black rhino was also placed on the list under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species but the numbers crashed from 80,000 in 1975 to 4,000 in 1990. So although it was banned by the international organisation, because of the activities of the poachers and the value of the rhino horns, the rhinos were a lucrative source of income for the local people and the numbers fell quite dramatically.

The situation arises that Western countries expect poorer nations to protect their species by way of police forces et cetera but, with their very low level of productive wealth, this is a great burden on some of the African communities. In pre-colonial days, the local communities regarded the elephant as a valuable source of food and hide. Local people developed strategies to manage the population numbers effectively, to guarantee the survival of the species. So there was an incentive to keep the elephant numbers up and not shoot elephants for the value of their tusks. Once this incentive for the locals was lost, there was an encouragement to destroy the elephants for the value of the ivory, either in a commercial sense or in the sense that the poachers could use what were almost minor armies to poach the animals and then sell the ivory on the open market or the black market.

Another interesting comparison is the Basel convention on the trade of hazardous wastes, a similar proposition put forward by the Greenpeace organisation, which states that Third World countries cannot trade toxic or hazardous wastes from OECD countries to non-OECD countries. Although we might agree with the sentiments of that convention, a similar outcome emerges in that the developing countries lose the comparative advantage they had in terms of labour costs and stand to lose under it.

As occurs with the banning of drugs, the banning of the sale of ivory in Western markets encourages a black market. It does not guarantee that the numbers of elephants will be maintained and the poachers are encouraged to get bigger, better and more effective. There is no real notion of private ownership by the village people of the elephants and therefore no incentive to keep them in their current numbers. So the African nations illustrate the need for an incentive to maintain the endangered species, if we put the elephants in that category. The local people need to have an interest in keeping them in their current numbers and derive some commercial benefit from doing so.

I want to refer to another interesting example of endangered species that the honourable member for Scullin and I inspected on the trip to Bangladesh and Nepal. In Nepal there is an interesting exercise aimed at encouraging people to maintain their forests. Before I continue, I want to pay tribute in this chamber to the very outstanding leadership given to the delegation by the honourable member for Scullin over the three weeks—

TALK.START.PARA: —He'll be quoting you in the election campaign.

—I am not voting for him at the Hobart conference but he is a colleague and a friend of mine in other matters. To continue, when we visited the minister for forests, Mr Bir Mani Dhakal, he discussed the Nepal-Australia community forest project and the very important change of attitude among the local people—similar to that relating to the elephants—that the Australians had managed to encourage at both the government and local level.

PARA.TAB: The legislation that the government has introduced, at the behest of the Australians, includes the concept that a percentage of the forest be put back into local and private hands. The new management plan anticipates that 60 per cent of the forests will eventually be controlled by local communities, with 40 per cent remaining as state forest. That is a key change of attitude and policy by the government. It is based on the premise that if the locals take over control of their forest area they will maintain it and ensure that regeneration takes place, so that the forest and species that are being depleted across the face of Nepal will be regenerated.

As the honourable member for Scullin will recall, we looked at areas throughout Nepal where this policy has been put in place and vast areas of bare landscape are now beginning to be covered by new forests. Our report about the project states:

SPEECH.PARA: The success of the NACFP projects is based on the principles of profit and sustainable development. Villages look after the forests because of the community gain. Trees are grown for commercial exploitation and the plantations are safeguarded by villages who use the prunings for fuel. There is a financial incentive to increase the amount of land under forestry, and so regeneration is encouraged. There is another performance indicator: NACFP officers reported an increase in the number of leopards seen in the hills, indicative of the increased forest cover.

Delegation members were particularly impressed with this project, not only because of what we saw on the ground but also because of the underlying philosophic thrust behind this change in attitude that tour leader Bill Jackson explained to us.
