We were impressed with the way in which the local people had embraced this change of attitude. We were told of improvements in a number of areas, including in the amount of fuel available for villages, the sawlogs that emerged from the particular forest areas we inspected, the regeneration of the forest cover and the lack of erosion. This recovery is occurring after 300 years of devastation through the cutting down of the country's forests.

PARA.TAB: It is a very good example of what we should be doing in Australia. We should be encouraging the authorities, and, in my view, the private sector operators, to put some commercial value into the forest operations and into endangered species—if we can put them all into that category that the Australian people are generally concerned about. With some commercial incentives, endangered species—the fauna and flora, and the national parks—might be protected and their reproductive capacity encouraged in a similar way to the situation in Nepal and Africa.

It is my view that national parks run by governments tend to send signals to the community of another nature. The community takes the view that national parks, say in Victoria, are the responsibility of `them'—that is, the government—and not of the local people, so there is a great tendency for the locals not to be worried about fire, about a build-up of rabbit population or the fuel that caused such a massive disaster on Ash Wednesday. If there is a turnaround in the attitude towards forests and national parks so that people develop a feeling of ownership of those public assets, then they would care for them in a more personal way, as do the people in Nepal.

In terms of the forests in Victoria and throughout Australia, a similar attitude could be developed whereby people would have some personal ownership. I notice that endangered species have become the key element in the argument about locking up forests rather than whether the forest is sustainable in its own right. My investigations indicate that forest practices in the 1990s suggest that forests are sustainable, that the logging process and regeneration will ensure that forests will go on as they have over the last 2,000 years. Endangered species, such as the koala bears in the south-eastern forests or the owl in northern America, are not the key elements. They become a focal point in public debate about the forests, but let us look also at the capacity of the forests to be sustainable over the long term and provide products as is the case in Nepal.

To conclude, I say that my remarks on this occasion at least relate to the bill, compared to those of the previous speaker who was very much keener on developing some arguments against his own colleagues in the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Mrs M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill is short and uncomplicated and aims to amend, and in some cases to repeal, a number of different acts administered within the portfolio of environment, sport and territories. The territory of Christmas Island is sovereign Australian territory. It was transferred from its status as a British colony in 1958 to Australia. Australia has asserted sovereignty over Christmas Island since that time. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is of the view that our claim is soundly based in law, both domestic and international. Thus, the actions of government and the determinations of ministers have the power of law.

PARA.TAB: This bill removes the anomaly of a single word, `exclusively'. Ministerial delegation of power exists in relation to Christmas Island and, therefore, the suggestion that only ministers can act is misleading. This bill clarifies that point. In 1955 sovereignty over the Cocos (Keeling) Islands was transferred from the United Kingdom to Australia. Prior to this act the islands had been annexed by Britain in 1857.

The islands, which are now permanently and legally part of the Commonwealth of Australia, are believed to have been discovered by Captain William Keeling of the East India Company in 1609 but remained uninhabited until small settlements were established in 1827 by John Clunies-Ross. The Clunies-Ross family, famously associated with the Cocos Islands, began the development of the copra industry with the aid of imported labour. The permanent inhabitants of the islands today are Australian citizens and are descendants of the original labourers who were principally of Malayan, Indonesian, Chinese and African extraction.

The bill seeks to clarify the use of ministerial discretion to enable the minister to delegate powers in relation to the exercise of Commonwealth law in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Both Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have, respectively, administrators appointed by the federal government and responsible to the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). These territories are not part of any Australian state. Perhaps that situation will not go on forever and we can look forward to a further normalisation of life, whereby these islands become municipalities and do not need to be governed by Canberra officials. However, that development is undoubtedly some way down the road as yet.

National parks and wildlife conservation is a major activity of government. The triumph of the environment movement over the past 30 years has been to create an environmental awareness in almost every person in Australia. This is a very great achievement and one upon which we must build. Of course, our environmental concerns are not an end in themselves and we are careful with the environment because it is in the interests of human life to be so. The world exists for the benefit of humanity and it is therefore a solemn duty for all people to care for the environment in which we live.

As part of our increasing awareness of our environment, the rights and the realities of Aborigines—the first Australians—have also become more prominent. An example of this awareness is the correct use of the Aboriginal Australian names for prominent parts of our country. The prime example is the former Ayers Rock. We now accept that the first Australians knew of this magnificent site long before the rest of the Australian family arrived on this continent.

The amendment bill enables the renaming of the site to be by act and not just by a proclamation. The change to Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park is small, but not cosmetic. We are a long way from our declared goal of reconciliation with the first Australians with whom we share this land and who are central to our national family. May I point out that during the recent parliamentary recess I had the opportunity to go to Uluru National Park, and it certainly is an inspiring sight. Once seen, the red sand there is not forgotten.

This bill deals with the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, and part of that act was directed at preserving the most essential part of natural biodiversity. This is a growing problem today. Government officials involved in this matter should be ever vigilant. Building on the 1975 act, in 1988 the government established an endangered species advisory committee which had a number of objectives. It aimed to develop a national strategy that would seek to conserve endangered wildlife—plants and animals—and their habitats and prevent further species and habitats becoming endangered. The committee also aimed to promote management practices that will ensure the recovery of endangered species; to provide a national forum for the discussion of relevant matters; and to advise the minister on matters to do with wildlife preservation.

In 1989, the prime minister of the day announced a 10-year endangered species program, and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service was given responsibility for its implementation. We are now halfway through this 10-year program and this chamber and the nation at large would welcome an interim progress report on how effective or otherwise this program has been.

Biodiversity, wildlife preservation and the general maintenance of high environmental standards are of objective importance. It is not related to party politics at all. I would be the first to admit the genuine care and concern for environmental matters of honourable members opposite and I am keen that a higher level of bipartisanship should grow up in this chamber on questions as vital as these matters.

This bill also seeks to amend the Urban Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974. This act is principally concerned with the policy that the Australian government may agree with a state government upon the level of financial assistance to be provided by the Australian government for expenditure by the state on mutually agreed programs. This act had a momentous impact on the day-to-day life of the people of Australia when it was first passed. For the first time, it set the framework for the concept and function of cooperative federalism in Australia.

This act allowed the federal and the various state governments to work together in certain cooperative measures to improve the quality of life in Australia. We cannot allow the psychology of `she'll be right' to prevail in Australia. We must marshal our nation's resources to deal with the development of our country. This act did this and still can do it if we want to use it. Ad hoc programs—concrete bandaids—based on limited and grudging funds will never achieve the level of development that this underdeveloped nation needs if it is to grow and contribute to the improvement of life for all Australians.

When this act was passed in 1974, 85 per cent of Australians lived in urban areas, and that figure is unchanged. The act was not uniformly successful, although there were some achievements. The act has a three-point program directed towards urban areas, and each point is worthy of itself and indeed worthy today to be a current government policy.

Firstly, the act provided for the Australian government to work with the states to change the growth pattern of Australian cities. The policy was to cut back the growth of larger capitals such as Melbourne and Sydney and to promote alternative population centres. Secondly, the act sought to ensure that the continued although slow growth rate of the major cities avoided the problems of the past. Thirdly, the policy sought to arrest and to, in fact, reverse the decline of the general urban environment of our great cities and to improve the services within them. All these policies were interconnected and the success or failure of the policy required, and still does require, a coordinated approach.

Recent efforts by the Australian government to achieve a high level of cooperation between the various levels of government on this continent on matters of competition policy and human rights compare poorly with the success of a similar meeting 20 years ago. On 22 October 1973, a federal Labor minister met with the state ministers—Labor, Liberal and National—and agreed on a framework for urban and regional renewal which became the framework for the act which we are today seeking to amend.

It is an example of what politicians can actually achieve, irrespective of party concerns, when they put Australia first ahead of other considerations. The Hansard of 14 November 1974, at page 3557, says:

SPEECH.PARA: We agreed that we were united in our support of the following basic objectives: to contribute to the orderly and pleasant development of urban areas and in their broad planning and the assembly of land for urban purposes; to assist decentralisation through the development of attractive government centres; to ensure that the rise in values from governmental announcements of growth centres accrues to the community rather than to individuals, and to ensure the lowest possible prices for urban land: and to achieve all this for the benefit of the people with the assistance of the Australian government funds. At that meeting the State Ministers agreed that the Australian Government should remove the artificial and detailed categories under which funds for urban and allied purposes were currently being offered by the Australian Government.
This quote shows that cooperation on matters of great national policies is not only desirable but possible. Our federation must be a cooperative one or we will cease to be a federation.

PARA.TAB: The amendment bill before us today repeals sections that are particular to the time of the original act. However, honourable members who, in fact, do have the welfare of Australia at heart can look at the act which we are amending and, by use of a little imagination, can see that our national progress has been based on cooperation. If all the political parties could cooperate on policy matters in the politically overheated mid-1970s, then surely today we can regain a level of intergovernmental cooperation at least equal to those famous years.

This amendment bill seeks to repeal three complete acts of parliament. They are: the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1930, the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1933 and the National Fitness Act 1941. As honourable members know, when our federation was being put together there was a great and heated debate about whether Sydney or Melbourne should be the national capital. Many and varied and good, and spurious, arguments were advanced in support both of Sydney and Melbourne. Being a Melbourne born and raised girl representing a Sydney electorate, I will pass silently over this matter of great contention.

As we know, Canberra was the wisdom of Solomon type solution in deciding between the two wrangling cities. The legislation giving statutory power to section 125 of the constitution was eventually put into the two seat of government administration acts of 1930 and 1933. These acts are now obsolete and the requirements of section 125 are established elsewhere.

We can all be proud of the 90 years of work done by men and women in producing the Canberra that we have today. I doubt that there is finer urban environment anywhere in the world. It is a triumph of Australians' desire to have something beautiful. I do think, however, that the future city should emphasise human work other than government work, so that the future Canberra is more balanced and less a government hothouse.

That said, I do not stint in my praise for the vision of successive governments for this place. Praise should go to Sir Robert Menzies for insisting on the creation of Lake Burley Griffin. Praise should also go to Malcolm Fraser for deciding to build this parliament building, and praise should go to all the members of this parliament, present and past, for not being daunted in their quest to build this beautiful city. In many respects, Canberra is a model of Australian urban design which puts people first.

The final piece of legislation to be repealed is the National Fitness Act 1941. Unfortunately, war requires healthy young men and women, and this act allocated money in the area of physical fitness. National health and welfare also require a reasonable standard of physical wellbeing in the country. Australia today is much better serviced by various sporting and health conscious organisations. This is an ongoing matter, and the government is right to emphasise physical wellbeing in our community.

As an example of the benefits of physical wellbeing, I direct the attention of the committee to the magnificent Australian Commonwealth Games team in Canada. This week we have seen Australia's greatest gold rush since Kalgoorlie was discovered. The psychological impact on Australia of our team's success is beyond measure and, through the Australian Institute of Sport, we have paid for the team's success. A nation needs encouragement, and victory gives encouragement. Victory requires hard work, and hard work needs a healthy physique. Our team—our sons and daughters—is the apple of our national eye.

I am involved in the Olympic subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Watching these wonderful Australian athletes perform in Canada, I am redoubled in my determination to ensure that the Sydney 2000 Olympics will be the highlight of Australian peacetime existence.

Our national unity is based on a psychological commitment to this continent and to all the people living here. Our expressions of this unity are our national efforts, and the Olympics will be such an effort. We shall not fail, as our team in Canada has not failed. We shall make every effort, as our team has made every effort. We shall prove to ourselves that we are a people of substance and unity.

The National Fitness Act 1941 laid a foundation stone that has now been covered by a great edifice—the edifice of a strong and healthy nation whose exemplars are bringing us such credit in Canada today. I trust that the government gives these returning heroes the mightiest welcome home any of us has ever seen. I commend these amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that I have had the opportunity to speak in the Main Committee and, as such, it is the first time that I find myself on this side of the fence. Over the few weeks that the Main Committee has operated in sitting time, it has done so very successfully. I thank those who are involved in the conduct of this chamber: those who assist from the speaker's panel, like yourself, in chairing; the clerks who give us advice; and the whips' officers who have taken on an additional workload and who ensure that the place runs smoothly.

PARA.TAB: The standard of discussions and debate in this chamber is similar to that which occurs down in the main House of Representatives chamber. However, it is adopting a different flavour, even though I might just mention the behaviour of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon), which at the start of today's session perhaps needed a little bit of improvement, though I am sure he can be re-educated.

We have a very minor piece of legislation before us, but that befits the fact that it was envisaged that non-controversial items would come up here. However, what was envisaged right from the start was that, whilst the legislation might be non-controversial, there was the opportunity for the debate to have a certain amount of controversy.

It is only coincidental that I have decided to make this speech from the cross benches. It is not a reflection or any sort of comment on the comments of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) today in this debate. He showed that honourable members of this chamber can still exercise their right to approach legislation, whether or not it is as simple as that before us today, in a very forthright way and can expand and present to a debating chamber such as the Main Committee a broad range of issues that can be properly discussed.

Whilst I would have to agree that the person occupying the chair at the time showed a great degree of leniency, I did think that his was a very wise decision, because it was appropriate that the honourable member use this opportunity—under the guise of speaking on the piece of legislation which is being amended: the urban and regional development legislation—to put the views that he did about issues such as the FAC and matters to do with the privatisation of that organisation.

As has been outlined quite adequately, not only in the second reading speech but by people such as the honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), there is a series of pieces of legislation which are repealed totally by this bill. Although that has been adequately covered, I note that one of those is the National Fitness Act, and I cannot pass up this opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), who indicated to me today that he is undertaking quite a fitness campaign by walking around in the very brisk mornings that we confront here in Canberra. I suppose that those flippant remarks are an indication of how, in the 1990s, there abounds in the community a different attitude to fitness matters, one quite distinct and different from that in the 1940s, when it was felt necessary to put in place, as a measure during the war, the National Fitness Act.

Other pieces of legislation that are amended, as has been indicated, are the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. It is appropriate that the parliamentary secretary—who has just entered the chamber and will, I am sure, behave—is a beneficiary of the amendments to be made, because it will be procedurally easier for him to administrate under these acts in the territories since, as a member of the Executive Council he, like his fellow members of the Executive Council, will be given power to use the powers that are delegated under these acts.

The next pieces of legislation that are amended, admittedly only in a minor manner, are the Endangered Species Protection Act and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. As others have used the opportunity in this debate, I intend to make some comments about the matters that are covered by those two pieces of legislation.

From the outset, we should acknowledge the work of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, which is the principal authority that deals with matters under these two pieces of legislation. Of course, the agency was created back in May of last year, and was the new name for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. In announcing that change in name, the then minister said that the new name better reflected the wider role that the agency had. Indeed, if one looks at the annual report of the agency, one can see that it does have that wider role.

In its work with endangered native species, of course, the agency takes up the provisions of the legislation from 1992. One of the principal things that the agency is undertaking at the moment, of course, is the identification of endangered species and communities. Anybody who follows a number of the debates that occur in environmental matters would understand that one of the recurring difficulties is that there are often no benchmark levels by which to test that what is actually occurring is positive and is achieving the aims. That problem can be seen in a wide range of matters.

My good friend and colleague from the other side of the chamber, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), devoted his speech in this debate to forestry management. Forestry management is, again, one of those areas of recent environmental debate that has suffered because that debate did not have the necessary basic information so that that debate could go forward sensibly. On both sides of the argument we had distortions of what people necessarily believed was the actual case. So any work that goes on in any of these areas that establishes what are the base levels of what is happening at the moment is very important.

Of course, if we look at the area of endangered species, we must look at the factors that cause the threat to such species. An endangered species is, by definition, a species that might go into extinction because of a series of identifiable causal occurrences. Some of those causal occurrences or processes might be things such as habitat destruction or degradation of the habitat. Examples of that might be salination, grazing by introduced herbivores and other such things.

Threatening processes might be introduced animals, whether they be predators or simply competitors. They might be introduced plants. One example of that in the Northern Territory is Mimosa pigra. If one looks in the annual report of ANCA, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, one sees that that has been a recurring problem in some of the parks and reserves that it manages in the Northern Territory and is one of the areas that it is tackling.

In fact, because of ANCA's activities with Kakadu, it realised that one of the real problems was that the seed source of a lot of the mimosa infiltration into the park was outside the reserve and that there was really a need to have a look at those that controlled neighbouring areas to bring the Mimosa pigra problem under control. For instance, it recommended that there be Commonwealth funding towards the control of Mimosa pigra in the neighbouring Arnhem Land country. It is very important that those sorts of things go on, and agencies such as ANCA are to be applauded for that.

The final category of threatening processes to endangered species is direct exploitation, whether that be through collection or hunting or fishing and the like. All these factors have one thing in common, that they can be controlled by the species homo sapiens. That is very important. Whilst other animals and plants may be the problem, it is in our control to be able to address those problems and to ensure that, wherever possible, endangered species can be protected.

I mentioned that there are also amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. I have outlined the work that is going on through ANCA. That agency also controls reserves on Christmas Island and Cocos Island. There is the Christmas Island National Park on Christmas Island and on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands the reserve is mainly North Keeling Island, which is listed on the register of National Estate. I cannot remember now whether it is still subject to negotiations or has been confirmed as a fully fledged park or reserve. In both those areas ANCA does a lot of work.

If one reviews the history of Christmas Island, one of the main problems has been the degradation that has occurred to the rainforest as a result of the years of phosphate mining. One of the projects that ANCA is involved in is the rainforest rehabilitation program which uses phosphate export royalty payments which came from the former Christmas Island Phosphate Company. One of the aims in that rehabilitation program is to ensure that the habitat of the endangered Abbott's booby bird is preserved and rehabilitated. Anybody who has visited Christmas Island would understand its rich diversity of bird life. Another significant animal form on the island is the crabs. These two are quite reliant on the rainforest habitat; they are reliant on people trying to improve and rehabilitate those areas that have been mined whilst ensuring that the areas that have not been disturbed remain undisturbed.

The final piece of legislation that is affected by the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974. When I saw that the honourable member for Werriwa was on the list of speakers, I had an inkling that he might speak about that aspect of this bill. I had not worked out that he would do it in the way he did but I acknowledge that he has a great interest in the area of urban and regional development.

TALK.START.PARA: —And privatisation of airports too.

—The honourable member for McPherson is uncharitable enough to suggest that what the honourable member for Werriwa was doing was a practice run for the Hobart conference of the ALP. He should also observe that we talk about national parks and the changes I mentioned in Kakadu. I have gravitated to this position in the chamber on the curve of this cross bench. I hope that Kakadu and the Ranger mine alongside do not become the topic of conversation at the Hobart conference as well. It could be that we could open up—perhaps, in a warped sense, to the delight of those opposite—and have our public discussions as a party here.

PARA.TAB: As I said by way of interjection, one of the great strengths of the Australian Labor Party is that we have a great capacity to have these types of debates but at the end of the day we understand that there is mutual benefit from all travellers within the party understanding who the real enemy is or what the real outcomes that we want to achieve are and being able to achieve them.

If we go to those parts of this bill that repeal section 9, I think it is, of the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1974 and make minor amendments to section 10 and substitute a new schedule, we should perhaps also go back to the time in 1974 when under the Whitlam government this legislation was first introduced. It is interesting to note the comments of the Minister for Urban and Regional Development, the honourable Tom Uren, at that time. In his speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time it sets the seal on the concept and function of co-operative federalism in Australia.
Before that he said:
. . . it will have a momentous impact upon the day to day lives of the people of Australia.

At the moment, as we saw with what happened in Darwin at the COAG meeting, there is a sense of deja vu and a bit of cooperative federalism revisited. One of the real problems is that since 1901 when the colonies came together in a federation, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) observed a few days ago, the colonies, now the states, have seemed to think that federation was in some way a benefit for them and the constitution was cobbled together purely to protect some of their rights.

PARA.TAB: I think that the basis of what happened in the run-up in the late 1890s and in the run-up to 1901 and federation was that we created a nation. Perhaps as Australians that should be our first interest. Perhaps all the other matters of jealousies between the colonies are long gone and should be forgotten. One of those things that the piece of legislation in 1974 hoped to achieve was a national outlook on the way in which our urban and regional areas developed. As Tom Uren said at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: The great merit of this Bill—
being the original bill—

is that for the first time the resources of Australia are marshalled to provide national strategies and national programs. It is the first attempt by an Australian Government to recognise the national character of the problems of the cities. In particular it allows the Australian Government to join State and local authorities in planning and implementing programs with a broad national perspective.
It is unfortunately still the case at the moment that there is a need to revisit this question and a need to develop strategies that will give this national outlook.

PARA.TAB: Before being elected to this place, I was a member of a council in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. At the time I was elected, in the continuing momentum that was first started during the Whitlam years, there was a huge program of works to bring sewerage to suburbs that at the time had been in existence for some 20-odd years, and to areas that were undergoing subdivision in the absence of that basic infrastructure. If we go back to the reason why that was able to be completed towards the end of the 1970s and the early 1980s in the Melbourne metropolitan area, we find that it was because of the impetus that was given during the Whitlam years.

If we now look into the 1990s, we find that in cities such as Perth the federal government has come back to having an involvement in the provision of what is a fairly basic form of infrastructure for housing development, sewerage, by the funding that has been made available in Western Australia under the better cities program.

There has to be a realisation that the Australian government, as the national government, can have a constructive role in these questions of urban and regional development, because many of the issues of infrastructure provision are matters that fit under that umbrella. There is a need to understand that there has been a tendency for the overall provision of resources for infrastructure development to be diminishing, and I think we need to redress that.

That can only be redressed by the cooperation of the Australian government, the various state and territory governments, and local authorities. It will only be achieved through that cooperation—through a realisation that there are mutual outcomes that must be addressed. I am certain that this federal government will continue its work in ensuring that there is a national outlook and focus to the questions of urban and regional development. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay The Hon L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This omnibus legislation before the committee at present, the Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, streamlines a number of minor anomalies in the environment and sport areas and repeals some obsolete legislation. All these amendments may appear technicalities, but they nevertheless reaffirm the government's commitment to consistent management of some of our most important national heritage treasures, and of urban and regional development.

PARA.TAB: One small but significant amendment is to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. It is a simple replacement of two words, but it is the culmination of several years of effort by the government to ensure proper recognition of the rights and cultures of our indigenous peoples. The amendment simply replaces the words `Ayers Rock' with `Uluru-Kata Tjuta' in the act, enshrining in legislation the government's recognition and respect for the traditional owners and the important cultural role of this landform. Uluru is recognised around the world as a symbol of central Australia, and is one of the most important and well-known individual landforms in Australia; but around the country there are many other significant landforms that need to be protected by legislation and that we should take some cognisance of.

In my electorate, we have a significant landform in the Wolli Creek area, which is said to reveal in its geological biography ancient oceans that once occupied a significant part of eastern Australia. It is said by geologists that this is the only example of this type of landform left in the Sydney basin. But unfortunately, the state Liberal government in New South Wales is paying a little less respect to this site: it plans to run a tollway through the area. Of course, it has carried out an environmental impact statement, and that does make reference to the site, but, unfortunately, after identifying this important natural occurrence and its uniqueness, the government admits that it will have to—as it euphemistically phrases it—`reconstitute' this heritage-rich area laden with rare species, landforms and archaeological sites. I am not quite sure how one reconstitutes an area, but if it is left to the Roads and Traffic Authority we can be pretty sure how that will occur.

The EIS also identifies midden deposits along the general area of the tollway route, and says that these may contain historic as well as prehistoric material. However, the EIS's appraisal of the impact of the tollway on middens and those sites is summarily dealt with. It is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Surface disturbance will be minimal, therefore impacts on archaeological sites would be negligible.

What the EIS is saying here is that there will be one great slab of concrete, followed by tar, slapped on the sites. They may be buried for all time, but, according to the EIS, the impact upon them is `negligible'. I must admit that the EIS does detail mitigative measures, such as hiring an archaeologist `to give particular attention to selection of access roads and depots for the construction works.' The EIS says that a `detailed archaeological study' should be carried out. In other words, the EIS does not include an archaeological survey, despite the indications of the significance of the site. The EIS also states that archaeologists should monitor the excavation of the tollway in areas identified as having this type of archaeological potential. Of course, that is all great stuff, but one would have thought that some of this work would have been carried out in the EIS stage itself, before the government digs up, damages or buries our heritage for all time.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the New South Wales government treats the impact of the tollway on residents in a very similar fashion. Of course, if the state government had considered its urban transport future requirements, and done some decent planning for its residents, fulfilling its responsibility to provide adequate public transport, we would not have these black, ugly scars running through Sydney. If the New South Wales government and the Roads and Traffic Authority, which, like the Federal Airports Corporation, is bureaucracy out of control, do not start providing adequate public transport Sydney will do more than resemble Los Angeles: it will surpass Los Angeles for the number of people using cars, and for air pollution and smog, in what should be one of the most beautiful cities in Australia. If the New South Wales government did its job, there would not be a need for the continual drain and demands on the federal coffers to rectify this mess.

This leads me to the amendments to the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act before us today, and I will follow up some of the points made by my colleague the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I am sure the House does not need reminding of the numerous benefits contained in the government's regional development strategy as outlined in the Working Nation white paper announced in May. But the Committee might need to understand that this strategy and the subsequent development of a program ensure that, in future, disasters such as the ones that I have just discussed relating to the tollway in south-western Sydney and, more particularly, Sydney airport, do not occur again.

As honourable members will know, contained in the regional initiatives announced in the government's regional development program is a substantial amount of funding to ensure a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek, and to ensure that that airport is speedily built. As far as the people of my electorate are concerned, the building of the second airport cannot come soon enough. People have dithered about Sydney airport since the early 1970s, and probably back into the late 1960s—

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1940s.

—My colleague the honourable member for Shortland says it is back to the 1940s. Being a former transport minister, he would probably be more up on the minutiae than I. He always took a very principled position with regard to Sydney airport, which was that we should develop another regional capacity outside Sydney; and that is what the government is now doing. The recent conclusions of the so-called community consultation process on the draft noise and air quality management plan that the FAC has put out has only driven home the message of how vital forward regional planning is to the preservation of our city's quality of life and the preservation of the environment.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members may recall that the Commonwealth government agreed in 1991 to go ahead with the expansion of Sydney airport on the proviso that noise and air quality management plans were introduced to ensure that Sydney residents and the environment were properly compensated and protected from further intrusion by the air transport industry. The community submissions on these draft plans concluded on 12 August. I am told that thousands of submissions by individuals, affected residents, community groups and organisations—and one that I submitted myself—have been forwarded to the draft noise and air quality management plan steering committee which comprises the Federal Airports Corporation, the New South Wales Department of Planning, the Environment Protection Authority and the Civil Aviation Authority. That committee will consider these proposals and inclusions in the final draft of the plan which will be out later this year.

In fact, yesterday my office received a call from a constituent who complained that when he sought to pick up a copy of the draft noise and air quality management plan, just three weeks into the public exhibition and call for comment, there were no copies of the report left, making it extremely difficult for him and other residents to make a submission on the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: These draft plans, I believe, have only served to highlight how intrusive and regressive a ste this expansion of Sydney airport has been for Sydney, and south-west Sydney in particular, for the residents and the environment in which they live.

PARA.TAB: The problems and the high costs associated with inadequate regional planning have been driven home to the community, the government and industry alike. We must now ensure that industry is never again permitted to act so intrusively and without regard to its responsibilities to the community. Unfortunately, what has not been driven home is the need for an adequate process for the community to ensure that basic or minimum quality of life standards are maintained. The plans are completely inadequate. They do not go far enough in any shape or form. They do not propose to fairly compensate all noise affected residents, nor do they propose adequate noise mitigation. They do not even examine the full impact of the expanded airport's operation on people who live around the airport. Driven by economic expedience rather than the industry's responsibility to behave as a good neighbour, these drafts highlight how ridiculous it is even to attempt to have industries such as airports regulating themselves. As I said in the submission that I made to the inquiry, the most disgusting flaw of the draft plan is the total disregard for a community which was established long before Sydney airport was expanded in the way it is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The airport was there first.

—No, the airport was not there first; the people were there first. Marrickville and that part of south-west Sydney was settled in the 1800s. There had been flourishing suburbs around Kingsford Smith airport when it was a racecourse. It was turned into an airport in the 1940s and it was a small airport. What my colleague from the Gold Coast does not realise is that Sydney is becoming different from all the other major cities in the world.

PARA.TAB: In every other large capital you have an old 1940s or 1930s style airport close to the centre of the city and you have the major airport for the city out on the city rim. In New York, in London, in Paris, in Rome—in all the major cities of the world—the big international operators are out on the city rim and the smaller domestic operators are close in to the city; and that makes sense. It makes more sense in Australia than it does in Europe because, unless they are coming from New Zealand, people who are coming to Australia on international flights are spending a minimum of seven hours on a flight. If they have got to spend another 20 minutes to get into the centre of the city after flying from Singapore or from Hong Kong or from Bangkok for seven or nine hours, they are not going to say, `Shock, horror.' No-one comes from London to Sydney and goes straight to a meeting, or comes from Los Angeles to Sydney and goes straight to a meeting. Another 20 minutes will not hurt at all.

It made good sense to put the major operators out on the city rim. The Fraser government should have recognised that when it did the major airport needs study for Sydney in the early 1970s. The current government has finally recognised it—albeit, in my view, a little bit too late. I think it was a mistake to build the third runway, and what we should have done was build a much larger airport out at Badgerys Creek. Minister Brereton, to his credit, has recognised this; and the government in the last budget allocated a substantial amount of money to upgrade Badgerys Creek from being the sort of airport you were going to have when you were not going to have an airport to a proper, large airport that can take wide-bodied jets. That is sensible planning, and it should go further: the people who live around the airport in Sydney should not be the ones who have to pay the price for the increased tourist capacity that Sydney is experiencing.

To get back to the noise management plans, 20 per cent of the people who responded to this plan said that their sleep was disturbed by the airport. So while the authors of the draft management plan recognise that noise disturbance to residents from aircraft is significant—even now, before the operation of the third runway—they refuse to recognise the responsibility that the airport operators have to the community and include in the proposed noise mitigation program those areas that were in the 20 ANEF zone outside the airport's operation.

This so-called noise management plan, incredibly, does not consider, other than in a passing mention, the recent changes to air traffic management known as the standard take-off and arrival system. It is about time that a master plan for Sydney airport was developed, ensuring strategic needs of the aviation industry are met and incorporating responsibility to, and the needs of, the community. As the community now perceives the Federal Airports Corporation to be in breach of its own legislation requiring it to be a good neighbour, the FAC should in future only be allowed to assume an advisory role in the development and implementation of these plans.

Further, the current curfew regulations need to be reinforced and strengthened by federal government legislation, with a system of penalties for commercial operators who breach them. It is obvious that the people who live around Sydney have to pay some attention to helping with the prosperity of Australia, and they have been reasonable. Members might recall that the curfew at Sydney airport used to be 11 p.m. till 6 a.m. People have accepted that that might come back to 12 p.m. to 5.00 a.m.; but we now have international operators scheduling flights to arrive at Sydney airport around 5 o'clock. The curfew is not supposed to be lifted until 5.30 a.m., but we have now got scheduled flights leaving Europe to arrive at 5.30 a.m. This is just a joke. But of course, Mr Deputy Speaker, once the second airport at Badgerys Creek is operational—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I do not want to put you in a difficult position—it is obviously something that needs to be sorted out between the government and the opposition—but this is absolutely stretching things to the limit, as did the speech by the honourable member for Werriwa. I am sure the chief government whip knows this. This has absolutely nothing to do with this legislation at all. Whilst it might be appropriate for an adjournment speech or a grievance debate or even a private member's bill, I think it is setting a very dangerous precedent to allow this committee to be used in that way. Whilst the subject—and I am prepared to debate it any time—is a very important one to the people of Sydney, I think it is starting to set a very dangerous precedent if this committee is to be regarded any differently as far as the procedures for debate are concerned from the main chamber of the House of Representatives.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would have thought that the opposition whip might have known the legislation that was before the chamber. One of the bills that we are amending is the Urban and Regional Development (Financial Assistance) Act. That act allows the Commonwealth to agree with the states on various forms of Commonwealth assistance to be given for approved programs. One of those approved programs is the infrastructure that has been provided to go from Sydney airport to Badgerys Creek. I think what I am saying is precisely within the terms of the standing orders.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—There is no intention for there to be any difference in the interpretation of the relevant standing order in this committee from the main chamber. However, it has always been the case that reasonably wide ranging debates are permitted on second reading speeches and I therefore rule that the honourable member's comments are in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is the Solomon-like decision which one normally expects to get from you. I think you should take your colleague aside later and explain some of the finer points of these things. When your former colleague who is sitting opposite us here, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson), was the government whip, we never had these sorts of interventions from the opposition in attempts to take up people's time. The honourable member for Isaacs was far more efficient at this job than the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). But he is learning and he is only a deputy whip so he has got a bit of time to go.
—Could I suggest the honourable member for Watson is now off the subject and should return to the bill.
—It is boring to talk about the honourable member for McPherson; I should not do it. He is a nice fellow; he has just got to learn a little bit.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, what we need to do when looking at the legislation we have here that talks about parts of the environment and talks about Commonwealth assistance to states for projects is to look at these big projects like Sydney airport. As my colleague the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), the Deputy Speaker, said earlier, what Tom Uren had in mind with this sort of legislation when it was introduced in 1974 was that there would be some planning put into what happens with these big infrastructure programs around the major capitals of Australia because we cannot do these things in isolation.

The people who live around those projects are the ones who suffer. The additional standard of living of all Australians is raised by increases in tourism but it is a trade-off. The sensible thing is to have a smaller operating airport in the centre of the city and the larger international operator out on the city rim. That is good management; that is good urban planning and that is the sort of thing that the Commonwealth ought to be encouraging the states to do. At Sydney airport I think we have seen a failure in that sort of process. Let us hope that the extension of Badgerys Creek can help that out. I thank the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to acknowledge the contributions that have been made by various speakers. At the outset, I will limit my comments essentially to a discussion which was introduced into the debate by the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) and pursued to some extent by the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) about the relation of feral animals and exotic weeds to park management.

PARA.TAB: The contribution by the honourable member was a very interesting one and it raised some very important issues. I will respond in the context of acknowledging the role that is currently being played in park management by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and, in particular, the efforts which are being made by the Commonwealth through ANCA to control feral animals and weeds.

I am speaking from experience, not only because of my involvement in the portfolio but also because I live in the Northern Territory and I have a lot to do with Kakadu and other national parks. The park on Christmas Island and the park on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are both in my electorate. The only other two parks for which ANCA has direct responsibility in this context are at Jervis Bay and on Norfolk Island. I have to say that the highlight of the management strategies which have been implemented by the various park managers—at Kakadu by Peter Wellings, at Uluru by Bob Seaborne, on Christmas Island by Graham Beach, at Jervis Bay by John Williams, on Norfolk Island by Paul Stevenson and on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands by Geoff Tranter—is the way in which the issue of the control of feral animals and weeds has been addressed.

I thought, listening to the speech made by the honourable member for Barker, that he was suggesting that the Commonwealth should accept some responsibility for national parks in a generic sense. Clearly, we have a responsibility to accept that we must manage those parks which are within our province—that is, the national parks which are controlled and administered by ANCA—in a way which is in the interests of the wider community, and we must adopt the most advanced management practices. It is clear that, whilst the Commonwealth presents a shining example of developing coordinated and cooperative management systems for the control of feral animals and weeds, that is not always the case with state and territory park managers. It appears that they do not always have the resources to deal with these particular problems, or they may choose to direct their resources elsewhere.

In the case of Kakadu, for example, there are three enormous problems which are being addressed currently by ANCA. The first one, which has received a great deal of prominence, is the question of feral buffalo. Since the feral buffalo program was put in place in Kakadu some 70,000 beasts have been removed. That is a large number. It is a joint Northern Territory and Commonwealth program which is almost complete. It was reviewed last year by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which put up a considerable amount of money through the BTEC program, and the department found it to be very successful. The program now consists entirely of mopping up a small number of buffalo stragglers which were left over, using a very innovative method—one which has sometimes been used in caucus I think—that is, the `judas animal'. The judas animal is a buffalo, fitted with a radio collar, that is allowed to roam freely and in the process gathers other straggling buffaloes around it. I do not want to go too far with the analogy about the way in which parliamentary caucuses operate, but the herd is then shot from helicopters. The current program is being carried out by the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, with ANCA's cooperation and assistance. In summary, the buffalo eradication program is being carried out to the satisfaction of both the Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments and the review by DOPIE has confirmed the success of the program.

The other significant program is in the area of weed control, particularly the eradication of Mimosa pigra and Salvinia molesta. The Mimosa pigra program is very important and has been very successful, and it continues to keep Kakadu National Park free of significant infestation. It is an ANCA program only in respect of Kakadu. Outside Kakadu to the east, in Arnhem Land on the Oenpelli flood plain, there is an ongoing program funded by the Commonwealth. The program is carried out with the full cooperation of the provisional landowners through the Northern Land Council, ANCA and the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries and it has made significant inroads into a large infestation of Mimosa pigra. The program continues to be carried out with the full cooperation of all parties, including the Northern Territory government, and is expected to be fully successful. That is very important, because what is happening is that the program is operating in conjunction with the agencies in the Northern Territory.

The other organisation which is involved in developing a biological control is the CSIRO. It has been doing a great deal of work, funded by the Commonwealth, for the release of a biological control of the Mimosa pigra infestation. ANCA has also funded the CSIRO to carry out significant research on integrated control of Salvinia molesta. The outcomes of the CSIRO's research are being implemented by way of integrated biological control with physical and chemical control.

I am raising these matters to point out to the honourable member for Barker that, whilst it is true that there are significant problems involved in national parks with feral animals and weeds, the fact is that the Commonwealth has adopted a very responsible attitude to the parks it manages and has implemented strategies to control these things.

On the broad issue of feral animal controls, I think he is quite right. There is a great deal more to be done nationally for us to get a handle on feral pigs, for example, on rabbits and on the noxious weeds in the community. But it will be done only in cooperation with the various levels of government. It is not the Commonwealth's sole responsibility, but where the Commonwealth has responsibility, I think it has exercised it properly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Snowdon) agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 8 June, on motion by Mr Free:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening, when asked if I would speak on the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Bougainville, I had not had the opportunity to read it. Since then I have done a considerable amount of reading of it, and I found it very interesting.

PARA.TAB: In fact, a number of points in it were significant to me. The Chief of the Defence Force in Papua New Guinea, Brigadier-General Robert Dademo, and the Assistant Defence Adviser in the Australian section have actually both been at Portsea at the same time I was there. One of the areas that we had studied at that particular time in political studies was Bougainville, because way back in the early 1970s Bougainville had been an area of particular political significance. At the time Prime Minister Somare, the new Prime Minister of New Guinea, was looking at the implications of Bougainville, in particular its copper deposits and their significant financial implications for the area.

It concerned me to read Senator Stephen Loosley's comments in the preamble to the report, where he said that the delegation wished to record its concerns and distress at the news of the beating of Sir Paul Lapun and his family shortly after his visit to Bougainville. It appeared from the news reports that a gang of 15 armed men had attacked Sir Paul and his family and burned down his house in the mistaken belief that he had been given money by the Australian delegation. Sir Paul Lapun, a distinguished Bougainvillean, had simply made an eloquent appeal to the members of the delegation about the need for dialogue to begin among all parties to the conflict in an effort to find a solution.

I guess that sums up one of the difficulties with regard to Bougainville and some of the problem areas there. Australia proposed the visit as a background to the widespread concern not only in Australia but around the world about the conflict in Bougainville. We recognise, I think, that it is not an easy area to establish solutions in.

Some of the recommendations that have been proposed by the committee to try to establish and continue dialogue and to bring the groupings of people together to try to talk through some of the problems are an important factor. One of the difficulties and one of the things that probably concerns me most is the taking of lives as payback, if you like, that seems to have occurred over a considerable period of time.

In fact, when one looks back over this particular conflict and the five years of fighting, the duration of the fighting that has occurred is similar to the duration of the Second World War. It is significant that the conflict has gone on over that length of time. The longer it goes on, the more animosity between the groupings is likely to build up. We have seen many other parts of the world where animosities have developed and hatred has developed between groupings. The longer it has gone on, the more difficult it becomes to resolve.

I have been impressed by the way the report has been put together by the delegation. I guess we could not have got a more diverse make-up for that. I think that is significant because what it does is provide for the members of parliament in this country—and I think it does it very well, from reading the report—a spread of views on the way that the conflict has developed and ways in which it can be handled. It is not only important for the parliament that we had that spread of representation but also it is important for the people of Papua New Guinea and for the people of Bougainville to understand that the document that has been put together by this delegation actually provides a very broad based view. It is significant because many of the people in Bougainville, I guess, may have had concerns that the presentation by the committee may have had biases, but I do not believe, given the make-up of that committee, that that holds any credence whatsoever.

The biggest areas of concern that I have in the longer term are the number of schools that are currently closed and the port facilities that are limited, at best. The opportunities for advancement for these people are extremely limited at the moment. One would hope that the people who are fighting, irrespective of what side they are on, would consider the future generation. If they cannot get their act together in this generation to sort out the problems, they should at least think of the children and their opportunities for the future without an education and without the opportunities for decent hospital treatment. I note that the main hospital, which was considered one of the better hospitals in New Guinea before 1993, was burnt down.

These things all lead to a degradation of the infrastructure that is necessary within any society. I would hope that, in the process of the work that needs to be done in this area, some emphasis can be placed on the parties involved being able to recognise that it is not only this generation that is suffering but the generations of the future. Education does need to be provided for development.

The report recommendations endeavour to bring the people together to discuss these issues. One of the suggestions in the report was that, although alternative means should be provided in Bougainville if at all possible, we should be prepared to look at Cairns as a possible location if that cannot be done.

I think it is important that Australia has tried to avoid direct intervention in this process. I think it is also important that we highlight the fact that, if the solution is to be found, it needs to be found by the people on the ground there. Ultimately, they are the people who are going to have to live with the decisions that are made. Solutions cannot, I believe, be made without their being involved.

Also significant is the point that was made in the report regarding the reopening of the mines. There has been a lot of concern that people have only taken an interest because of the copper there and the dollar value that one could place on that copper. The point has been made that solutions should be found before that actually occurs. Clearly, if it is not done in that manner, then it could, and probably would, be said—certainly by many of the people in Bougainville who are opposed to the way that issues have been handled—that it was done purely for financial gains. My belief in this area is that the report is correct in trying to look at that issue and solve those problems before the financial rewards that may come out of the copper mines are in fact achieved. They must be solved in that manner.

I commend the report. I think that the committee has done an excellent job in putting it together. I believe that it is a very difficult situation, and one that could create instability in an area where certainly we in Australia would least want it. We should, wherever possible, assist in trying to get the parties together to resolve the problem, without our pushing an Australian viewpoint on it, and I think that is in fact really highlighted by the report.

I do not really have a great deal more to say, except to conclude by saying that the way that the delegation has tackled this report, with the range of views that are in it, will do a great deal towards at least expressing a broadly based view to the community and to the people involved in this conflict, who may at some stage read this report. Hopefully, it will provide them with a good basis to look at it from a bipartisan Australian parliamentary viewpoint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time that I have spoken in this chamber, and it is with a great deal of sadness that I do so. The reason I wish to deal with this, though, is that I felt it a great privilege that the parliament had allowed me to be part of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Bougainville, which brought down this report, Bougainville: a Pacific solution. In reality, we really have to see this document as an historical document. This delegation went to Bougainville from 18 to 22 April 1994 and, at that point in time, there was a certain ambience, a certain feeling and atmosphere that was pervasive.I now read in this morning's paper, `Rebels kill three PNG soldiers in Panguna'.

PARA.TAB: With all the people involved, I have got a great deal of respect for some people in political life for whom I had not had much respect before. I am talking about the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair); I came to know that man on that delegation, and I now have a great deal of respect for him as an individual and as a person who really had the warmth, love and respect of the people of Papua New Guinea. They call him the `one-time strong man'—which is probably quite appropriate, if you think of it in a humorous sense, but it was a measure of affection. I have nothing but respect and admiration for those people who were on the delegation with me.

I think it was broadly known that my views, based on what I saw in Australia, were such that they would be seen by the general community as being somewhat radical. I went over there because I have been involved in the peace movement for a long time, and I really do not like the idea of people dying for nothing. The salient point in the first recommendation in chapter 6, is this:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.1All conclusions and recommendations of this report should be read in an understanding of the fact that the Delegation was unable to talk to the BRA on this visit.

That was no-one's fault; it is just the way that it was. What we have really got to understand is that this report was relevant between the 18th and the 22nd, and probably a couple of months later. It was a window of opportunity that this report opened. Like all attempts at peace by well-meaning people who go over and do their part to try to stop bloodshed, and who try to bring about a sensible relationship between any of us, it is an attempt that has got a life span set by the commitment of those people to fulfil a common set of desires. In this case, the common set of desires is progress in peace.

PARA.TAB: We talked directly with Prime Minister Wingti and Deputy Prime Minister Chan and I have the utmost admiration for them. In my own heart I know—even though I am copping political flak in my area because I believe this—that when we spoke to them they had an earnest desire to get peace.

But we have seen what has happened in Bosnia-Herzegovina. My wife is Croatian, so that conflict in that part of the world has a special meaning to me. When Vukovar was getting blown apart, she was in the situation of seeing people that she knew on the television. The atrocities, the bloodshed, the stupidity of killing other people, when there is nothing to gain, I find very hard to deal with.

When we were over there in Bougainville, and when we came back and put this report together, we had, perhaps, high hopes that it would make a difference. But I read in the paper today that another three poor innocents have died. I do not care that they have got bloody khaki on and they are Papua New Guinea government soldiers—they are three innocent people who have died: for what?

I have spoken previously in the House about how I believe this erupted, and who I felt was responsible. I would suggest that not all, but probably some, of the others who were on this delegation disagreed with me on that. I put it down to greed and money, to lack of consultation and lack of respect—basic, honest respect for other people, whether they be villagers or managers of multinational companies. If people on a one-to-one basis do not respect other people then no deal can be brokered, no arrangement can be held. We are in a position where there are a whole lot of hidden agendas going on. I came back from this visit and, with Stephen Loosley, I spoke to the ACTU's international committee. They were happy to accept our report, because they knew that Stephen and I covered the gamut of politics on the Labor side. They knew that we were both sincere people who would not lie to them.

I believe that the offers that came from Wingti and Chan were on that basis. Chan had a very close association with Ian Sinclair, and they did not know me from a bar of soap. But I hope that the outcome of our meetings and our talks, some of which were in confidence, conveyed to them that we had a deep desire, not to make dollars out of the area, but to stop senseless, idiotic, stupid killings, and to give something back to those kids who have lost five years of their lives; perhaps they have lost their future. They understood that we really were talking about that.

It would now seem that that has all gone. Whose agenda is it? Who is pushing it? There were those who, perhaps, advised people not to negotiate peace, because there was some hope held up that the United Nations would intervene, that the Security Council would intervene. I know that these things have been said to the people on the BRA side. I believe that the people who said that to them said it in the context of well-meaning advice.

I have got to be frank. I am often criticised because I say that sometimes bleeding hearts get in the way of a sensible solution. I am often criticised because sometimes I say that you have to cop it sweet and that you have got to have a position. What are the people on Bougainville after? My goal in being involved in this whole thing is to allow them to have a dignified, free lifestyle and to stop the bloodshed.

Just for the record, the Australian of 25 August 1994 says that Papua New Guinea forces have occupied Panguna. So what? Anyone who believes that a military solution can be achieved in Bougainville is nuts. During the Second World War many of the people from my area were actually involved in the fighting in Papua New Guinea. One uncle of mine was there and another uncle flew over the top of it. There were thousands of Japs on one side of the island and thousands of Americans on the other side, and they could not do anything with each other.

What is going to happen? We are going to have a festering sore in this country. We are going to have kids who for the next 15 to 20 years will be paying the price for some other people's idiocy, and for what? If only I could see some goal; if only I could see that they will get something out of this. I am not a coward and I am not a pacifist: I am a peace activist. I have said it before in this place and I will say it again: if you hit me in the face once, I will say, `Stop'; if you hit me in the face twice, I will say, `You'd better stop'; if you hit me in the face a third time, I will take your head off. I am not one of the people who believes that there is no recourse to violence. If our country is invaded I will volunteer in front of my sons, because I do not want them to get involved, but I cannot see what is to be attained.

There are some people in this country who will object to what I am about to say, but I will say it anyway. There was a protracted revolution on the island of Bougainville. Those who won the revolution had 90 per cent support and then, because people went around blowing innocent people's heads off, they lost that support. That is sheer idiocy. The people of the island should be its legitimate controllers. There was a little window of opportunity; for a fleeting moment it was there. There was a chance that these people could have grabbed hold of peace, but it slipped through their fingers.

I do not know that there is any further contribution that I can make. I do not say that with any feeling of pride; I say it with a sense of failure. I can only use this opportunity to make a plea to Prime Minister Paias Wingti, to Deputy Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan and to Francis Ona. I say to them: `You are three human beings. Cut your titles out and you are the same as I was before 13 March. You are just ordinary people. For God's sake, have some compassion for those kids. Have some compassion for the women in the area who are dying from preventable diseases and from giving birth to babies. Have some compassion for the future of the people who are going to have to live together.'

One of the idiocies that I find about the conflict in former Yugoslavia—Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, call it whatever you bloody like, I do not care what you call it—is that those people have lived side by side for 1,000 years. They have been neighbours for 1,000 years, and for the next 1,000 years they are going to sit side by side. When are we going to find a situation when people start looking ahead and saying, `These people are going to be my neighbours for 1,000 years, why don't I sit down and start doing something about having some respect for their rights,' and dealing with it in that manner? Until that happens the Bosnia-Herzegovinas, the Rwandas and the Bougainvilles are just going to keep going on.

I would love a `Peace for 2000' movement to start. I think we have got to start appealing to people's better selves and their better inner judgments. I think we have go to start appealing to people as individuals and saying, `This is wrong.'

I supported this report as a very good and honest approach in that window of opportunity to bring about peace. I can stand before you people and the Australian people and say that my whole goal was to try and get a peaceful settlement with respect for all. But I have got to say to you that this is an historical document; and whilst everything was pertinent and right and correct when it was brought down, I think it has had its day.

Unless these people want to stop bloodshed, unless they want to stop idiotic killings of people and deaths that is unwarranted, then I am afraid that an historical document is all this will ever be. Maybe I have wasted my time; but what I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that to try and save a life is worthwhile. If I had been able to achieve this and then stayed here for another 50 years, it might have been the biggest thing that I ever achieved. Unfortunately, that is not the case. I just plead with the people who are involved: talk peace, not war—if you do not, you are losing the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address the contents of the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Bougainville, like the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) I want to say that this is the first occasion I have been in this Main Committee. I take the opportunity to congratulate the Chairman of Committees and his deputies, the clerks, and the whips on both sides of the House. I think it is a worthwhile initiative and I think it will, over the coming months and for the remainder of this sitting year, go from strength to the strength that it clearly deserves.

PARA.TAB: In terms of this report, I would like first of all to congratulate a number of people. I agree with previous speakers that the members of the delegation were clearly a very diverse group. I want to congratulate Senator Loosley, the leader of the delegation and my colleague in the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I think that Senator Loosley here and elsewhere continues to make a major contribution in those portfolio areas, with a great deal of bipartisanship.

I also congratulate the deputy leader of that group, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). During the visit Mr Sinclair showed his experience as a previous minister for defence, and his great experience in dealing at the diplomatic level with lots of people.

Senator Vicki Bourne I congratulate also, and I am sure she made a very worthwhile contribution during the visit to that troubled island, as did Senator Paul Calvert and, of course—last but by no means least—the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gilmore. I understand the emotion that he generated this morning. Having visited the island of Bougainville—and I will talk about that in a moment—I can understand what he is saying.

Finally, I am delighted that Margaret Swieringa is sitting in here. I think the delegation is only as good as its support and I am pleased to see her here. I am sure she made a very worthwhile contribution on the ground and also, very importantly, in the formal preparation of what is a very worthwhile report.

The visit was clearly a successful one. But as the honourable member for Gilmore has said, it will be only as successful as the Papua New Guinea government allows it to be. I do not agree with everything that he said. Nevertheless, I think he made a very valid point in saying that the initiative lies very squarely at the feet of the government of PNG.

I will not take the time of the committee for very long this morning, but I think it is worth reading into the record the opening to the synopsis of the report, because it encapsulates everything that the delegation set out to achieve. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The war on Bougainville has lasted for over five years. It has cost many lives, destroyed infrastructure, dislocated life on the island and yet attempts to find a solution for the crisis appear to have reached an impasse. A military solution is not possible for either side, but without political resolve—
this takes up the point of the honourable member for Gilmore—

there is the likelihood that the conflict and the suffering of the Bougainvillean people will continue indefinitely. Finally, the conflict has the potential to drain Papua New Guinea of its resources, to undermine its unity and to damage its international reputation.

Events on Bougainville are vital to the stability of Papua New Guinea and ultimately to the region. Australia's interest in Papua New Guinea, its prosperity and its stability, is longstanding and continuing.

It is important that we reinforce that point and include it in the record of this committee. I think the visit was successful. To understand why it was successful, honourable members do not have to go any further than to read the foreign minister's response, the government response, to this report. In part, Senator Evans said this:

PARA.TAB: The delegation's visit has been very successful in two important respects. The first of these is having provided an authoritative eyewitness account of the current situation on Bougainville and in providing the Australian parliament and the Australian community with access to the views of ordinary Bougainvillean men and women, unfiltered by spokespersons seeking to promote the views or cause of any one side. The delegation makes clear in its report its overwhelming impression that the people of Bougainville, above all, desire peace and a return to normal life.
