In doing so the report also helps to dispel some of the misrepresentations which propagandists have promoted, especially here in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans further stated:

Secondly, the delegation visit has, I think, itself served to encourage renewed Papua New Guinean efforts to seek out a peaceful solution. This report provides useful suggestions as to how a peace process might develop on the PNG side while at the same time stating a possible basis for an appropriate Australian contribution to the process. It does not lay down a prescriptive, detailed blueprint for peace; it does clarify the very real issues that do need to be addressed.

I think that the foreign minister has hit the nail on the head and that this has been a successful visit. However, once again I have to agree with what the honourable member for Gilmore said, that it will only be successful in the medium to longer term if the government of PNG has the will to do something about the real problem that exists in Bougainville.

PARA.TAB: In looking at the way ahead, again Senator Evans made some good points. I think it is worth reading into the record of this committee what he said in two paragraphs of the government response, because once again I think it encapsulates exactly where we should be heading and perhaps where PNG should be heading. He said this:

Those parties who remain opposed to Papua New Guinea sovereignty in the North Solomons are faced with a choice: to continue pursuing their political objectives through violence and intimidation, or to set these aside in the interests of allowing ordinary Bougainvilleans to resume their normal lives, to educate their children, to cultivate their food gardens, to plant their crops, and to travel freely. Compromise must be seen to come from all sides.

It is the government's sincere hope that the delegation's report will encourage all those involved in the Bougainville situation to think more seriously about peace and about the steps needed to bring it about, and to take at least the first of those steps without waiting for others to set the pace. The government has, in this respect, welcomed the recent confirmation by Papua New Guinea Foreign Minister, Sir Julius Chan, that he has held discussions with South Pacific nations on ways in which they might help to bring an end to the conflict. It may be that, depending on the task envisaged, Australia could play a role in supporting a small regional peacekeeping force, established to facilitate a peace process. This has not yet been put to us as a detailed proposal, and we await further elaboration of the concept. We would certainly consider any such proposal very sympathetically.

SPEECH.PARA: I think those comments have a lot to attract the attention and the support of this House. I was very concerned in reading the report because although it is a long time since I have been to Bougainville, perhaps 10 or 12 years, what I did see in reading the report was the disaster that clearly is Bougainville. When I was there, Arawa port was a bustling port, the Panguna mine was open and working, and the people in that area were a bustling community. Clearly, all of that has been destroyed. In particular, as the report sets out, there have been problems with human rights atrocities. The degree of those, of course, is debatable, but nevertheless it is clear that there have been certain atrocities on both sides of the camp of conflict.

PARA.TAB: In terms of health, I notice that the report made the point that in the three years between 1990 and 1993 over 500 people died of disease which could have been avoided had the facilities been there. I also note that 60 schools remain closed. That, of course, is not in the interest of PNG children, and the future of PNG lies very firmly with its youth. Also the report made the point that the infrastructure—the roads, the airfields et cetera—has been degraded to a point where a lot of money will have to be spent to re-establish it to the level at which it should be.

I do not want to take up the time of the committee unnecessarily, but I will make a couple of final points. It is in Australia's strategic and security interests that we have stability to the north, and of course Papua New Guinea is an important element in that regional stability. This report makes very valid points. It provides an appropriate set of leads both for this government and, more importantly, for the government of Papua New Guinea. But I reaffirm and reiterate what the honourable member for Gilmore said in his contribution to this debate: it will only happen if the people and the government of New Guinea have the will to make it happen—and that perhaps has had some setbacks in recent days and weeks—but the onus lies fairly and squarely with that government.

Finally, I would like also to congratulate the government of Papua New Guinea, particularly Prime Minister Wingti and foreign minister, Sir Julius Chan, obviously during this delegation visit and recently, although a lot still has to be done. I also would like to congratulate the staff of the High Commission in Port Moresby, from the High Commissioner down. Clearly, from reading the report, without them the visit would not have been possible because of the very demanding and very dangerous conditions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend this report to the committee. It has a lot to offer and I hope that this country will be given the opportunity to provide further support in the appropriate areas that are highlighted in the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, because this is my first opportunity to speak in this new committee, I wish to say how much I welcome its introduction into the parliament. I also extend my thanks to you for your work, supported by the Speaker and others in the parliament, in helping to establish it. I first saw a committee such as this in the House of Commons some years ago when I represented the Victorian parliament. I was very impressed with its ability to scrutinise legislation in an informal manner and in a very effective way which involved the ministers, the parliamentary secretaries, the shadow ministers and, in the case of the day I was with the committee of the House of Commons, the permanent head of the department. So that was an interesting amalgam of people.

PARA.TAB: I am also very happy to be able to make a brief contribution in support of this report, as a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It gives me a chance to pay a tribute to Senator Loosley, the chair of that committee. He brings all of us together from the various political colours in a very skilful way. I must say it is a pleasure to participate in that committee. It has also been a pleasure for me, as a very new member of this parliament, to see the colour, talent and experience of the various members of that committee and, indeed, the parliament.

Of course, the father of the House, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), played a very important part in this delegation to Papua New Guinea. I never cease to be amazed, whenever I travel around Australia with the right honourable member for New England, to see the number of people visiting here from all over the world who know him and come up to him. He instantly recognises them and immediately they are able to find some common denominator. His knowledge, which he imparts to all of us, in what I might say is a very humble way, is important to the parliament.

It was also interesting today for me to hear the contribution of my colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). It never ceases to amaze me how a parliament which is made up of so many diverse people can bring together so much experience and talent. The honourable member for Isaacs was confiding to us today that, during his time of officer training as a professional soldier in Australia, he trained with Robert Dademo, who is now the Commander-in-Chief of the PNG defence forces. They were young soldiers together, and here today we see one of those colleagues speaking about the Bougainville situation.

The points that have been mentioned by the previous speakers have covered important areas of the report which I would have referred to, so I am not going to go over those again. I was pleased to see the report is a unanimous report and one would expect to see, under Senator Loosley's chairmanship and a certain secretary's skilful, crafted writing, that the report would come out and reflect the views of everyone. The report is terribly important because it virtually is, as far as I can understand, the first significant report about a serious situation in Bougainville by representatives of the Australian parliament. It also provides a very sensible foundation for future action, without attempting to impose Australia's opinion or will on the people of PNG and Bougainville.

I hope that the suggestions about a series of community meetings, to bring people together and to enable them to put their views, will ultimately culminate in a conference, in Cairns or perhaps somewhere else. Above all, it should be held in a place where the people of PNG-Bougainville feel comfortable and relaxed. I hope that it will occur. Even though three people were unfortunately killed yesterday in an ambush, and even though we realise that problems arise constantly—almost daily—we must not lose faith or hope that the recommendations of the committee will eventually lead to a conference and to ongoing discussions.

Although I am not able to say what we talked about at the meeting this morning of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, we had representatives from Israel speaking to us about the long process of peace. They spoke about how, although peace has not yet been achieved, significant progress has certainly been made and how Yasser Arafat is seen in a different light now from the one in which he was seen some years ago. I think we ought to draw some hope from the fact that if everyone of goodwill works together and maintains a common goal, eventually they will succeed, as will, I am sure, the government and the people of PNG and Bougainville.

As my contribution I want to record in Hansard some of the comments made by the people themselves to the delegation when the delegation was welcomed and when it left. I think that will provide some perspective and some balance to today's excellent contributions by the other speakers. Nick Peniai, who is Chairman of the South West Interim Authority, made a speech when the delegation arrived on 21 April. All of his speech should be read—it is in the report—but there are some points that struck me as being significant and as giving a lead. He talked about things that could be done by Australia and by others to help. On page 64 of the report his speech says:

SPEECH.PARA: However, we believe that this essential area of activity must now be supplemented by other activities as a pre-requisite to establishing a sound economic base for South West District. In this we are seeking the goodwill of people like yourselves, Australian Government agencies or donor agencies for that matter to actualise our visions.
I love that `actualise our visions'—that is nice. He continues:
We have for some time now contemplated the establishment of some light industries suited to our environment and able to provide labour and employment to our youth.
We have got a bit in common there, have we not? Mr Peniai continues:
These range from manufacture of clothing for the tropics, soft drinks, light vehicle maintenance, workshops, car sales and steel fabrication plant.

I have a lot of friends in Australia in industry and commerce and in service groups and I am going to take that back to them. I honestly believe that there are a lot of people in Australia in the private sector and in the volunteer community who would like to know that, and who could go over there and perhaps help to introduce and develop some of the activities which lead to employment, economic growth, stability and, of course, the opportunity for people to lift themselves out of poverty. Nick Peniai continues:

We submit that the transfer of appropriate technology and knowledge is a vital obligation of the industrialised West. We therefore urge you to take cognisance of our muted requests so that we can ford the rivers of incompatibility together into the 21st century.
He also says:

Those who choose to remain in the bush have vowed to fight to the last man. For what reasons, we do not know. But one thing we do know of is that their refusal to come out and join us to work together is based on the hatred that they have for individual Bougainvilleans.
To bury the hatchets as it were and to look forward to a new day of hope, of peace and of prosperity.
They are very appropriate words, but they indicate some of the problems that have yet to be tackled.

PARA.TAB: Another speech was from Thomas Anis, chairman of the Buka Interim Authority and spokesperson for the chiefs and other leaders of the North Solomons Province. I thought his input was very important, too, because he obviously knows a lot about the North Solomons history and some of the problems that need to be taken into account in trying to find peace in that area. I am reading from page 71. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In this regard, the chiefs and the people of the North Solomons Province see the current arrangements of power sharing between the National Government and the province as the ideal basis for discussions on a lasting solution to the Bougainville crisis.

It is our honest conviction that no amount of force and physical confrontation will enable us to address these issues and other issues which gave rise to the problems which have devastated our lives and the lives of our children.

He referred, in conclusion, to Australia's special role in helping to achieve all of those matters. I welcome the report. It is a very good report. I congratulate the members of the delegation and the staff and I look forward to chapter 2, which inevitably will occur—we hope, very soon.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Ms Crawford) agreed to:

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 3 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: What action has the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) taken to implement each of the recommendations of the 1993 Prices Surveillance Authority inquiry into the aeronautical and non-aeronautical charges of the FAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Following an inquiry which began in November 1992, the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) made a number of recommendations on the Corporation's aeronautical and non-aeronautical charges to the Government in August 1993.

The Government considered the PSA's report in the context of a broader review of the FAC's performance, pricing and capital structure and accepted the broad thrust of the PSA's recommendations. The Prime Minister's `Working Nation' statement of 4 May 1994 announced that the Government would introduce reforms to improve the FAC's investment and pricing decisions. These reforms will be achieved through the phased introduction of economically efficient pricing principles. The practical implementation of these reforms will be considered as part of the scoping study into the possible sale of Federal airports.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Risk Management Program

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 30 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did he refer in answer to a question without notice from the then Leader of the Opposition on 3 May 1994 (Hansard, page 34) to an internal audit report addressing fraud in his Department; if so, will he provide (a) a copy of the report or a summary of all the recommendations of the report and (b) details of his Department's response to each recommendation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The report referred to was an internal audit of the Department's Program Administration and Statistical System (PASS) which is the principal means of making payments under the various labour market programs. The actions taken in response to the audit report have significantly reduced the Department's exposure to fraud in the labour market program area. A summary of all the recommendations of the report and the current status of each is appended.

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Training and promotion of the (Financial Control Guidelines) manual be developed and maintained so that users understand how to apply the contents of the manual. This should reflect a needs analysis of staff administering programs throughout the Network.
Status as at 1 June 1994—A draft financial control and program administration handbook has been prepared. It is due to be released and promoted to the CES in July 1994.

2. Consideration be given to the establishment of a financial control help desk facility in the States and Territories to provide support to OICs and Regional Managers in interpreting the manual. This would serve as a feedback mechanism to ensure the content of the manual was able to include common problems identified by the help desk.
3. The procedures for creating and maintaining program information, including who had the delegation to perform these functions, should be documented and communicated to the relevant officers.

4. Sufficient procedures should be set in place to ensure adequate segregation of duties (between creation of a program category in PASS and certification of payments) occurs. These procedures should ensure that persons who can create a new program category cannot also certify claims.

5. We recommend that signatures should be provided with Instruments of Delegations supplied by the Program areas to the PASS Team. Instruments of Delegations should contain the position numbers associated with the maximum amount that a person may approve.
6. Internal Audit recommends that PASS be modified so that mandatory validation procedures can be used to determine the existence of a provider in PASS.
7. That FINEST notify PASS users of any changes to the supplier file which have an impact upon the PASS provider file.
8. A single Departmental supplier file or an arrangement which achieves the objectives of a single supplier file be used for all applications within the Department.

Work is under way to improve the quality of data within the supplier files for all financial systems. This is due to be completed in late August 1994 and ongoing data integrity checks are currently being developed.

9. That an analysis of the PASS provider file be conducted immediately, and repeated periodically, to identify duplicate providers. When a duplicate provider is found the relevant outlet office manager is informed so that the duplicate provider can be deactivated.

10. A project should be recorded on PASS prior to or on the day of commencement. Given that a contract creates financial obligations, a project should be created before its commencement date so that payments to clients and providers can be made promptly.

11. A table be maintained in PASS specifying the maximum period after commencement for which a project may be created within a particular labour market program. This function will not allow the PASS user to create a project exceeding the maximum period specified by the table.

12. An ageing report should be produced indicating projects that have been modified over 3 months after the commencement date of the project. This report should be reviewed at the relevant State Office or Central Office level and feedback given to the office in which the modification was performed.
13. Project approval should occur prior to the commencement date of the project to ensure that the correct commencement date has been entered.

14. There may be circumstances where the information used to set up a project in PASS is incorrect for a range of reasons, such as incorrect keying or renegotiation of the terms of the contract. A modification facility may be required to allow modification of the project details. The use of this modify function should require the re-application of the approve function, with the appropriate segregation between the officers who perform the modify and approve functions.
15. PASS should not permit users to create projects years into the future. Projects should not be created in PASS more than 12 months before their commencement dates.
16. Segregation of duties should be implemented between the create/modify function and the authorisation function, to ensure that the creation or modification of a provider are bonafide.
This will be addressed as part of the development of a corporate client file.

17. At the creation of an additional project record for a provider a manual override is available. An audit log should be available to track and report on these occurrences. A second override should be required if the project details are identical.

18. Providers who fail to acquit by the due date should not receive any further contracts. The PASS system be modified such that the creation of any other financial obligations against a provider is not possible until acquittal has been carried out.
Not completed. Controls are being introduced to the extent practicable to prevent further payments in respect of the contract for which the acquittal was outstanding.

19. The responsibility for implementing these recommendations rests jointly with the Assistant Secretary, Information Systems Development Branch and Assistant Secretary, Planning and Performance Branch. Program managers in the network are to be made aware of this recommendation.
20. We recommend that PASS be modified such that overpayments are recovered from any labour market program which the provider is involved in.

21. That the feasibility of providing a facility to record and track under and over acquittals be undertaken. It would enable the certifying officer to make an informed decision about making subsequent payments to a provider. ideally such a system should indicate when a payment to a provider is to be stopped. The responsibility for ensuring that this recommendation is implemented rests with the Assistant Secretary, Information Systems Development Branch.
22. We recommend monitoring the extent to which manual calculations for regular payments occur, particularly where such calculations exceed the amount calculated by PASS.

23. Consideration should be given to incorporating a function within PASS that will not allow a PASS user to modify Formal Training Allowance (FTA) or wage subsidy commitment beyond the maximum calculated by PASS.
24. We recommend that PASS be changed so that all advance payments are properly flagged for future acquittals.

25. Extension of the placement beyond the originally approved cessation date should require the placement to be reapproved. The reapproval requires segregation of duties between modify and approve functions, consistent with the creation of the original placement.

Internal Audit notes that currently an extension requires reapproval; however this function is performed by a single officer, which does not reflect an appropriate control regime. Internal Audit accepts that a single officer may vary the cessation date to shorten the period of the placement.

26. The report "Listing of Placements Open Beyond their Planned End Date" should be reviewed at relevant Regional or Area Offices and feedback given to PASS or Program Management stating the reasons for delays in closing placements. On the basis of reviewing the ageing report produced by PASS, PASS management could consider the appropriate period in which a placement can remain open.

27. Internal Audit notes that Employment Programs and Services Division (EPSD) is reviewing its reporting structure, which currently focuses on the Operational Plan, Newstart and Financial Planning. Within this review, EPSD should consider the inclusion of information on placements open beyond their planned end date, disaggregated by State and Program as part of the monthly expenditure report. It is noted that this report should go to the Budget Monitoring Committee and to the Executive.
28. Internal Audit recommends that consideration be given to a number of measures to ensure reconciliation of DSS and PASS data including:
(a) the inclusion of a tape beginning and end messages, or using a hash total to ensure complete and accurate transmission;

(b) creation of a stack in DEET recording all information dispatched to DSS from PASS. Data dispatched from DSS to PASS should be matched with the data in the stack. Where matches occur the data should be deleted from the stack. Where the DSS record does not match a record in the stack, the record should be included in an exception report. These mismatched records should be investigated or returned to the DSS. Periodically, at least weekly, an ageing report on data in the stack greater than two weeks old should be provided to identify those records not included in DSS tapes for follow up with the DSS.
29. The OCES code should be incorporated with each record on the PASS to DSS tape in such a way that error reports can be targeted to particular offices for correction.

30. The gross amount paid by DSS should be passed through the interface transaction file and be reflected in PASS records. That is, the gross amount should be recorded in FINEST and against the client record in PASS.

31. Internal Audit strongly supports the current efforts being made to correct the errors that have been made. We also recommend that FINEST reconciliation procedures be implemented so that detection of these errors and timely correction of them can take place.
32. Procedures should be developed and implemented to ensure that reconciliation is performed to ensure that information received by PASS from JOBSYSTEM is both complete and accurate.

33. Segregation of duties should be implemented between registering changes to payee details and certification. This segregation should be enforced across systems, including PASS/JOBSYSTEM. Consideration should be given to elimination of the capacity to vary Jobseeker details in PASS.
34. Active clients in PASS should be retained in JOBSYSTEM until they have been archived in PASS.
35. Regular reconciliation of the two databases should occur in order to ensure the equivalence of common data held in both JOBSYSTEM and PASS.
36. That PASS be reconciled to FINEST on a monthly basis to ensure that the payments received by FINEST are complete and accurate.

37. The remaining ACF2 based logons be located and deleted. The responsibility for ensuring that this recommendation is implemented rests with the Assistant Secretary, Information Systems Development Branch.
38. Procedures should be developed so that the number of logons deleted and existing are recorded.
39. We recommend that a review of PASS users should occur at least annually. This review should ensure that all users are authorised and that their level of access is appropriate to their position.
40. User IDs should be checked against NOMAD to determine if they are still current. Those User IDs that have not been used for at least three months should be deactivated.

41. Corporate Services Division in consultation with System Division's Security Section should develop a Departmental separation checklist to ensure access to Department systems and other relevant matters are addressed at the time of separation. This may also be extended to address movement of staff within the Department.

42. The audit reports generated from PASS should be altered so that they are useable by State and Area office management. Given that, in some circumstances, it can take many months for a project to be created, audit reports covering two months are inadequate. PASS Management may need to store less data for longer periods for the purpose of audit reports.

43. PASS Management continue to monitor, evaluate and correct faults in PASS reports. PASS management should consider the ongoing use of SAS programs to examine the accuracy of reports once reports are in the production environment.

44. In addition, PASS management should promulgate the need for budget information to be entered so that Performance Indicator reports are meaningful. Unless information relating to targets are inputed, the reports using this information are meaningless.

FINEST—refers to the Department's accounting and financial reporting management system. It is a national online real—time system where all data entered is immediately available and consists of accounts payable—receivable, ledger, budget, enquiry, purchasing, fixed assets and travel modules.
OCES—refers to Offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service.
JOBSYSTEM—refers to the Department's computer application which records and processes data on Jobstart and Newstart program clients.
NOMAD—refers to the Department's human resource management application used for processing of personnel salaries.
ACF2—refers to an access and security software package used by DEET to control access to mainframe computer applications and resources.
SAS—refers to a statistical software package used to perform statistical analysis on data held in computer applications.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Fraud

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 30 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many cases of suspected fraud in his Department have been identified since 1 January 1992.
(2) How and by whom were the suspected frauds detected.
(3) How many internal or police investigations were pursued consequent to suspicion.
(4) How many convictions resulted from the investigations.
(5) How many cases involved the (a) actual or (b) suspected wrongdoing of his Department's officers or agents.
(6) Which Departmental programs are involved in each suspected case.
(7) How many instances of (a) suspected or (b) confirmed fraud have occurred in each program.
(8) What sums were involved in each confirmed fraud case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) From the creation of the Fraud Prevention Section in November 1992 to 31 May 94, 552 cases of suspected fraud have been identified across all Departmental programs.

(2) The suspected frauds were detected as a result of departmental checks, including enrolment checking, investigations and data matching. They were also detected as a result of awareness raising activities of the Fraud Prevention Section, monitoring and other actions conducted by the Department or were identified to the Department or the Australian Federal Police (AFP) by outside sources or reported anonymously.
322 suspected frauds were detected by DEET staff, 115 were detected by outside sources and 115 were reported anonymously (either by DEET staff or by outside sources).

(3) Of the 552 cases of alleged fraud already investigated or currently under investigation the AFP has taken prime responsibility for investigating 40 cases. In a substantial number of other cases, the AFP has either been consulted or involved in joint investigations with DEET's Fraud Prevention Section. An estimate of the number of these latter cases is not available.
(4) In the period in question 120 convictions have been obtained. There is a lag of 1 to 2 years in completing cases involving prosecution action through the Courts.

(5) Departmental officers have been involved in 40 cases of suspected fraud. Of these, 22 cases are currently under investigation. Two officers have been dismissed and four have been imprisoned as a result of the 18 completed cases.
Instances of suspected and confirmed fraud in each program are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Program Of Cases Of Proven Fraud

PARA.TAB: (8) Confirmed fraud in the 305 completed cases amounted to around $775,000, with a range of individual amounts from $240 to $144,500.
